Attorneys for the mayor said that an amicable property settlement has been agreed upon.   The petition listed the mayor's occupation as "attorney" and his age as 71. _WASHINGTON, FEB& 9_- President Kennedy today proposed a mammoth    1.5127085093302464
new medical care program whereby social security taxes on 70 million    1.6065767145351917
American workers would be raised to pay the hospital and some other    1.6432600607208703
medical bills of 14.2 million Americans over 65 who are covered by    1.6432600607208703
social security or railroad retirement programs.   The President,    1.4513752902486308
in a special message to Congress, tied in with his aged care plan    1.67495327387791
requests for large federal grants to finance medical and dental scholarships,    1.6065767145351917
build 20 new medical and 20 new dental schools, and expand child    1.6432600607208703
health care and general medical research.   The aged care plan,    1.5636360329510388
similar to one the President sponsored last year as a senator, a    1.6432600607208703
fight on Capitol hill. It was defeated in Congress last year.    1.6065767145351917
It would be financed by boosting the social security    1.5127085093302464
payroll tax by as much as $37 a year for each of the workers now    1.7269387314284994
paying such taxes.   The social security payroll tax is now 6    1.6065767145351917
per cent- 3 per cent on each worker and employer- on the first $4,800    1.7026049541338664
of pay per year. The Kennedy plan alone would boost the base to    1.67495327387791
$5,000 a year and the payroll tax to 6.5 per cent- 3.25 per cent each.    1.7269387314284994
Similar payroll tax boosts would be imposed on those under the railroad    1.6432600607208703
retirement system.   The payroll tax would actually rise    1.4513752902486308
to 7.5 per cent starting Jan& 1, 1963, if the plan is approved, because    1.7026049541338664
the levy is already scheduled to go up by 1 per cent on that date    1.7269387314284994
to pay for other social security costs.    1.3761581156320553
Officials estimated the annual tax boost for the medical plan would    1.6065767145351917
amount to 1.5 billion dollars and that medical benefits paid out would    1.6432600607208703
run 1 billion or more in the first year, 1963. Both figures would go    1.7026049541338664
higher in later years.   Other parts of the Kennedy health plan    1.6065767145351917
would entail federal grants of 750 million to 1 billion dollars over    1.6432600607208703
the next 10 years. These would be paid for out of general, not payroll,    1.7026049541338664
taxes.    1.0
The aged care plan carries these    1.2818970554302986
benefits for persons over 65 who are under the social security and railroad    1.67495327387791
retirement systems: _1._ Full payment of hospital bills for    1.5127085093302464
stays up to 90 days for each illness, except that the patient would    1.67495327387791
pay $10 a day of the cost for the first nine days. _2._ Full payment    1.7269387314284994
of nursing home bills for up to 180 days following discharge from    1.6432600607208703
a hospital. A patient could receive up to 300 days paid-for nursing    1.6432600607208703
home care under a "unit formula" allowing more of such care for those    1.67495327387791
who use none or only part of the hospital-care credit. _3._ Hospital    1.6432600607208703
outpatient clinic diagnostic service for all costs in excess    1.5127085093302464
of $20 a patient. _4._ Community visiting nurse services at home    1.6065767145351917
for up to 240 days an illness.   The President noted that Congress    1.6432600607208703
last year passed a law providing grants to states to help pay medical    1.67495327387791
bills of the needy aged.    1.1606783668269585
He said his    1.0
plan is designed to "meet the needs of those millions who have no wish    1.7026049541338664
to receive care at the taxpayers' expense, but who are nevertheless    1.6065767145351917
staggered by the drain on their savings- or those of their children-    1.6432600607208703
caused by an extended hospital stay".   "This is a very    1.5636360329510388
modest proposal cut to meet absolutely essential needs", he said,    1.5636360329510388
"and with sufficient 'deductible' requirements to discourage any    1.4513752902486308
malingering or unnecessary overcrowding of our hospitals.   "This    1.4513752902486308

_OSLO_ The most positive element to emerge from the Oslo meeting    1.6065767145351917
of North Atlantic Treaty Organization Foreign Ministers has been    1.5127085093302464
the freer, franker, and wider discussions, animated by much better mutual    1.6065767145351917
understanding than in past meetings.   This has been a working    1.5636360329510388
session of an organization that, by its very nature, can only proceed    1.6432600607208703
along its route step by step and without dramatic changes. In Oslo,    1.6432600607208703
the ministers have met in a climate of candor, and made a genuine    1.67495327387791
attempt to get information and understanding one another's problems.   1.5127085093302464
This atmosphere of understanding has been particularly noticeable    1.4513752902486308
where relations are concerned between the "colonialist" powers    1.4513752902486308
and those who have never, or not for a long time, had such problems.    1.7026049541338664
The nightmare of a clash between those in trouble in Africa, exacerbated    1.6432600607208703
by the difficulties, changes, and tragedies facing them, and other    1.5636360329510388
allies who intellectually and emotionally disapprove of the circumstances    1.5127085093302464
that have brought these troubles about, has been conspicious by    1.5636360329510388
its absence.    1.0
In the case of Portugal, which    1.2818970554302986
a few weeks ago was rumored ready to walk out of the ~NATO Council    1.7026049541338664
should critics of its Angola policy prove harsh, there has been    1.6065767145351917
a noticeable relaxation of tension. The general, remarkably courteous,    1.5127085093302464
explanation has left basic positions unchanged, but there has been    1.5636360329510388
no explosion in the council. There should even be no more bitter surprises    1.67495327387791
in the ~UN General Assembly as to ~NATO members' votes,    1.5636360329510388
since a new ad hoc ~NATO committee has been set up so that    1.67495327387791
in the future such topics as Angola will be discussed in advance.   1.6432600607208703
Canada alone has been somewhat out of step with the Oslo attempt    1.6432600607208703
to get all the allied cars back on the track behind the ~NATO    1.67495327387791
locomotive. Even Norway, despite daily but limited manifestations against    1.5127085093302464
atomic arms in the heart of this northernmost capital of the alliance,    1.6432600607208703
is today closer to the ~NATO line.   On the negative    1.5636360329510388
side of the balance sheet must be set some disappointment that the    1.6432600607208703
United States leadership has not been as much in evidence as hoped for.    1.67495327387791
One diplomat described the tenor of Secretary of State Dean Rusk's    1.6065767145351917
speeches as "inconclusive". But he hastened to add that,    1.5127085093302464
if United States policies were not always clear, despite Mr& Rusk's    1.6065767145351917
analysis of the various global danger points and setbacks for the    1.6065767145351917

fixed its policy.    1.0

The secretary's    1.0

reduce the total amount of its payroll by 10 per cent through salary    1.67495327387791
cuts and lay-offs effective at 12.01 A&M& next Saturday. The    1.5636360329510388

of heavy goods has necessitated this regrettable action".   The    1.5127085093302464
reduction in expenses will affect employees in the thirteen states in    1.6065767145351917
which the B& + O& operates.    1.1606783668269585
It    1.0
will be accomplished in two ways: _1._ A flat reduction of 10 per    1.67495327387791
cent in the salary of all officers, supervisors and other employees    1.6065767145351917
not belonging to unions. There are about 3,325 officers and employees    1.6065767145351917
in this class. _2._ Sufficient lay-offs of union employees to    1.5636360329510388
bring about a 10 per cent cut in the union payroll expense.   Since    1.67495327387791
the railroad cannot reduce the salary of individual union members    1.5636360329510388
under contract, it must accomplish its payroll reduction by placing some    1.6065767145351917
of the men on furlough, a B&+O& spokesman said.   Those    1.5636360329510388
union members kept on their jobs, therefore, will not take a cut in their    1.7026049541338664
wages.   The spokesman said the number to be furloughed cannot    1.5636360329510388

a board member and long-time critic of the superintendent, argued    1.5636360329510388

Seventeen years ago today, German scientist Willy Fiedler climbed    1.5127085093302464
into a makeshift cockpit installed in a ~V-1 rocket-bomb that    1.5636360329510388
was attached to the underbelly of a Heinkel bomber.   The World    1.6065767145351917
War /2, German bomber rolled down a runway and took off.   1.6065767145351917
The only way Fiedler could get back to earth alive was to fly the    1.7026049541338664
pulse jet missile and land it on the airstrip. This had never been done    1.7026049541338664
before.   Now a quiet-spoken, middle-aged man, Fiedler is an    1.5127085093302464
aeronautical engineer for Lockheed's Missiles and Space Division    1.4513752902486308
at Sunnyvale, where he played a key role in the development of the    1.67495327387791
Navy's Polaris missile.   He sat in his office yesterday and    1.5636360329510388
recalled that historic flight in 1944.   "The first two pilots    1.5636360329510388
had crashed", he said. "I had developed the machines and therefore    1.6065767145351917
knew them. It was time to go up myself".   Fiedler was then    1.6432600607208703
technical director of Hitler's super-secret "Reichenberg project",    1.3761581156320553
which remained unknown to the Allies until after the war.   1.5636360329510388
About 200 of the special ~V-1 rocket-bombs were to be made ready    1.6432600607208703
for manned flight with an explosive warhead. The target was Allied    1.6065767145351917
shipping- a desperate effort to stave off the Allied invasion of    1.6065767145351917
Europe.   The success of the project depended upon Fiedler's    1.5127085093302464
flight.   Squeezed into the few cubic feet normally filled by    1.5636360329510388
the rocket's automatic guidance mechanism, the scientist waited while    1.5127085093302464
the bomber gained altitude.   At 12,000 feet, Fiedler signaled    1.5127085093302464
"release", and started the roaring pulse-jet engine- then streaked    1.5127085093302464
away from beneath the Heinkel.   To the German pilot in the    1.6065767145351917
bomber the rocket became a faint black speck, hurtling through the    1.6065767145351917
sky at the then incredible speed of 420 m&p&h&.   It was probably    1.6432600607208703
man's first successful flight in a missile. "She flew beautifully",    1.5636360329510388
said Fiedler. "There was only one power control- a valve    1.5636360329510388
to adjust the fuel flow. I had exactly 20 minutes to get down to    1.7026049541338664
the test strip".   Using a steering system that controlled the    1.5636360329510388
modified rocket's tail surfaces and wings equipped with ailerons,    1.5127085093302464
Fiedler was to land the missile on a skid especially bolted under the    1.67495327387791
fuselage.   He managed to maneuver the missile to a landing speed    1.6065767145351917
of 200 m&p&h&- fast even for a modern jet plane touchdown-    1.6065767145351917
and banked into the airfield.   Moments later the ~V-1 skimmed    1.5636360329510388
across the landing strip, edging closer and closer to a touchdown-    1.6065767145351917
then in a streamer of dust it landed.   Fiedler went on to make    1.67495327387791
several other test flights before German pilots took over the Reichenberg    1.6065767145351917
missiles.   The missiles were to be armed with an underwater    1.5636360329510388
bomb. Pilots would steer them in a suicide dive into the water,    1.6432600607208703
striking below the waterline of individual ships.   A crack corps    1.5636360329510388

PROBABLY THE hottest thing that has hit the Dallas investment    1.5636360329510388
community in years was the Morton Foods stock issue, which was    1.6065767145351917
sold to the public during the past week.   For many reasons, the    1.6432600607208703
demand to buy shares in the Dallas-headquartered company was tremendous.    1.5636360329510388
It was not a case of the investment bankers having to sell the    1.67495327387791
stock; it was more one of allotting a few shares to a number of customers    1.7269387314284994
and explaining to others why they had no more to sell.   Investors    1.6432600607208703
who wanted 100 shares in many cases ended up with 25, and customers    1.67495327387791
who had put in a bid to buy 400 shares found themselves with 100    1.7026049541338664
and counted themselves lucky to get that many.   In fact, very    1.6065767145351917
few customers, anywhere in the nation, were able to get more than 100    1.67495327387791
shares. Some Dallas investment firms got only 100 shares, for all of    1.6432600607208703
their customers.   A measure of how hot the stock was, can be    1.6432600607208703
found in what happened to it on the market as soon as trading began.   1.7026049541338664
The stock was sold in the underwriting at a price of $12.50 a share.    1.7026049541338664
The first over-the-counter trade Wednesday afternoon at Eppler,    1.4513752902486308
Guerin + Turner, the managing underwriter, was at $17 a share. And    1.6065767145351917
from that the stock moved right on up until it was trading Thursday    1.67495327387791
morning at around $22 a share.   But the Morton Foods issue    1.6065767145351917
was hot long before it was on the market. Indeed, from the moment the    1.7026049541338664
reports of the coming issue first started circulating in Dallas last    1.6065767145351917
January, the inquiries and demand for the stock started building up.   1.6065767145351917
Letters by the reams came in from investment firms all over the    1.6432600607208703
nation, all of them wanting to get a part of the shares that would    1.7026049541338664
be sold (185,000 to the public at $12.50, with another 5,000 reserved    1.6432600607208703
for Morton Foods employes at $11.50 a share).   There was even    1.6065767145351917
a cable in French from a bank in Switzerland that had somehow learned    1.67495327387791
about the Dallas stock offering. "We subscribe 500 shares of Morton    1.6065767145351917
Foods of Texas. Cable confirmation", it said translated. But    1.5127085093302464
E&G&T& could not let the Swiss bank have even 10 shares.   1.6065767145351917
After it allotted shares to 41 underwriters and 52 selling group    1.6065767145351917
members from coast to coast there were not many shares for anyone.   1.6432600607208703
But the result of it all was, E&G&T& partner Dean Guerin    1.6065767145351917
believes, an effective distribution of the stock to owners all    1.5636360329510388
over the nation.   "I feel confident the stock will qualify for    1.6065767145351917
the 'national list'", he said, meaning its market price would    1.5636360329510388

again his argument that Dallas investment men can do just as good a    1.67495327387791
job as the big New York investment bankers claim only they can do.   1.67495327387791

easy to find a stock priced as the Morton issue was priced (at roughly    1.7026049541338664
10 times 1960 earnings, to yield a little over 5 per cent on the 64~c    1.7269387314284994
anticipated dividend).   Second, the "potato chip industry"    1.3761581156320553

taken on the flavor of a "growth" industry in the public mind of    1.67495327387791
late. Foods, which long had been considered "recession resistant"    1.5127085093302464

to higher price-earnings ratios.   The potato chip industry these    1.5127085093302464

of circumstances    1.0

HERE'S an idea for a child's room that is easy to execute    1.6432600607208703
and is completely charming, using puppets for lamp bases. Most children    1.6065767145351917
love the animated puppet faces and their flexible bodies, and    1.5636360329510388
they prefer to see them as though the puppets were in action, rather than    1.7026049541338664
put away in boxes. Displayed as lamps, the puppets delight the children    1.6432600607208703
and are decorative accent.   To create such a lamp, order    1.5636360329510388
a wired pedestal from any lamp shop. Measure the puppet to determine    1.6432600607208703
the height of the light socket, allowing three to four inches above the    1.67495327387791
puppet's head. Make sure that the metal tube through which the wire    1.6432600607208703
passes is in the shape of an inverted "~L", the foot of the    1.67495327387791
"~L" about three inches long, so that the puppet can hang directly    1.6432600607208703
under the light.    1.0
Using the strings that manipulate    1.1606783668269585
the puppet, suspend him from the light fixture by tying the    1.6065767145351917
strings to the lamp base. In this way, you can arrange his legs and arms    1.7269387314284994
in any desired position, with feet, or one foot, barely resting on    1.6432600607208703
the pedestal. If the puppets are of uniform size, you can change them    1.67495327387791
in accord with your child's whims.   Although a straight drum    1.5636360329510388
shade would be adequate and sufficiently neutral that the puppets could    1.6065767145351917

The Leningrad Kirov Ballet, which opened a series of performances    1.5636360329510388
Friday night at the Opera House, is, I think, the finest "classical"    1.6432600607208703
ballet company I have ever seen, and the production of    1.5636360329510388
the Petipa-Tschaikowsky "Sleeping Beauty" with which it began    1.4513752902486308
the series is incomparably the finest I have ever had the pleasure of    1.67495327387791
witnessing.   This work is no favorite of mine. I am prepared    1.6065767145351917
to demonstrate at an ytime that it represents the spirit of Imperial    1.6432600607208703
Russia in its most vulgar, infantile, and reactionary aspect; that    1.5636360329510388
its persistent use by ballet companies of the Soviet regime indicates    1.6065767145351917
that that old spirit is just as stultifying alive today as it ever was;    1.7026049541338664
that its presentation in this country is part of a capitalist plot    1.6432600607208703
to boobify the American people; that its choreography is undistinguished    1.5636360329510388
and its score a shapeless assemblage of self-plagiarisms. All    1.5127085093302464
of this is true and all of it is totally meaningless in the face of    1.7269387314284994
the Kirov's utterly captivating presentation.    1.1606783668269585
The reasons    1.0
for this enchantment are numerous, but most of them end in "ova",    1.6432600607208703
"eva", or "aya". In other words, no merely male creature    1.5636360329510388
can resist that corps de ballet. It seems to have been chosen exclusively    1.67495327387791
from the winners of beauty contests- Miss Omsk, Miss Pinsk,    1.5636360329510388
Miss Stalingr **h oops, skip it.   These qualities alone,    1.5127085093302464
however, would not account for their success, and it took me a while to    1.7026049541338664
discover the crowning virtue that completes this company's collective    1.5127085093302464
personality. It is a kind of friendliness and frankness of address    1.6065767145351917
toward the audience which we have been led to believe was peculiar to    1.67495327387791
the American ballet. Oh-the-pain-of-it, that convention of Russian    1.4513752902486308
ballet whereby the girls convey the idea that they are all the daughters    1.67495327387791
of impoverished Grand Dukes driven to thestage out of filial piety,    1.6065767145351917
is totally absent from the Kirov. This is all the more remarkable    1.6432600607208703
because the Kirov is to ballet what Senator Goldwater is to American    1.6432600607208703
politics. But, obviously, at least some things have changed for    1.5636360329510388
the better in Russia so far as the ballet is concerned.   Irina    1.6432600607208703

the role before. She is the most beautiful thing you ever laid eyes    1.67495327387791
on, and her dancing has a feminine suavity, lightness, sparkle, and refinement    1.6432600607208703
which are simply incomparable.    1.0
Alla Sizova, who    1.0
seems to have made a special hit in the East, was delightful as the lady    1.7269387314284994

virile,    1.0

RECENT publicity attending the successful federal prosecution    1.3761581156320553
of a conspiracy indictment against a number of electrical manufacturers    1.5636360329510388
has evoked a new respect for the anti-trust laws that is justified    1.6432600607208703
neither by their rationale nor by the results they have obtained. The    1.6432600607208703
anti-trust laws inform a business that it must compete, but along completely    1.6432600607208703
undefined lines; it must play a game in which there never is    1.6432600607208703
a winner. The fact is that any business that wants to operate successfully    1.67495327387791
cannot follow the law. Hypocrisy thus becomes the answer to a    1.6065767145351917
foolish public policy.   Let us look at the heavy-electrical-goods    1.5127085093302464
industry in which General Electric, Westinghouse and a number of    1.5636360329510388
other manufacturers were recently convicted of engaging in a conspiracy    1.5636360329510388
to rig prices and allocate the market. The industry is so structured    1.6432600607208703
that price-setting by a multi-product company will vary with the way    1.6065767145351917
overhead charges are allocated- whether marginal or average pricing    1.5127085093302464
is applied.   The problem becomes even more complex where an enterprise    1.6065767145351917
is engaged in the manufacture of a wide variety of other goods    1.6432600607208703
in addition to the heavy electrical equipment. Accounting procedures    1.5127085093302464
can be varied to provide a rationale for almost any price. Naturally,    1.6432600607208703
enterprises of the size of General Electric are in a position to    1.6432600607208703
structure their prices in such a way that the relatively small competitors    1.6432600607208703
can be forced to the wall in a very short time. Should these giants    1.7026049541338664
really flex their competitive muscles, they would become the only    1.5636360329510388
survivors in the industry. Uncle Sam would then accuse them of creating    1.6432600607208703
a monopoly by "unfair competition". But if they show self-restraint,    1.5636360329510388
they don't get the orders.   Under the circumstances,    1.4513752902486308
the only protection for the relatively small manufacturers is to engage    1.6065767145351917
in exactly the kind of conspiracy with the giants for which the latter    1.67495327387791
were convicted. Engaging in such a conspiracy was an act of mercy    1.6432600607208703
by the giants. The paradox implicit in the whole affair is shown by    1.67495327387791
the demand of the government, after the conviction, that General Electric    1.6065767145351917
sign a wide-open consent decree that <it would not reduce prices    1.6065767145351917
so low as to compete seriously with its fellows>. In other words,    1.6432600607208703
the anti-trust laws, designed to reduce prices to the consumer on Monday,    1.6432600607208703
Wednesday and Friday, become a tool to protect the marginal manufacturer    1.6065767145351917
on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday. And which theory would    1.5127085093302464

back in 1937. He wrote: "(P& 211) **h the anti-trust    1.5636360329510388

_THE THREE-FRONT WAR_ At a closed-door session    1.3761581156320553

Hours after a parade of his new Soviet tanks and artillery, Dictator    1.6432600607208703

has now been reached".   Through Secretary Herter, Ike    1.4513752902486308

THE HEMISPHERE). _2) LAOS._ After a White House huddle    1.5127085093302464

At Geneva in 1954, to get the war in Indo-China settled, the    1.6432600607208703

beyond the five-cent fiction rentals, knows what it is to hear the librarian    1.67495327387791

Behind this reply, and its many variations, is the ever-present budget    1.6065767145351917
problem all libraries must face, from the largest to the smallest.    1.6065767145351917
What to buy out of the year's grist of nearly 15,000 book titles?    1.67495327387791
What to buy for adult and child readers, for lovers of fiction and    1.67495327387791
nonfiction, for a clientele whose wants are incredibly diversified, when    1.5636360329510388

inadequate. A startlingly high percentage do not exceed $500 annually,    1.5636360329510388
which includes the librarian's salary, and not even the New    1.5636360329510388

the wing of state governments, whereby, with the financial help of the    1.6432600607208703

that the radiation danger was far less than the danger of Communist    1.6432600607208703
world domination. Or it could have chosen to find- by negotiation-    1.6065767145351917

choices    1.0
are much the same. Only this time around the conditions are different    1.6432600607208703
and the choice is far harder.   The first choice, abandoning tests    1.6065767145351917
entirely, would not only be unpopular domestically, but would surely    1.5636360329510388
be exploited by the Russians. The second choice, full testing, has    1.6065767145351917

presupposes, as Russian behavior demonstrates, a great deal    1.4513752902486308

most important recent events in the New York theater.   They    1.5636360329510388
serve to contradict a popular notion that the Comedie merely repeats,    1.6065767145351917

us that the Comedie is not insensitive to criticism. The directors of    1.6432600607208703

how fortunate they are in having the world's finest fall coloring.    1.6065767145351917

 There is    1.0

The death of a man is unique, and yet it is universal. The straight    1.7026049541338664
line would symbolize its uniqueness, the circle its universality. But    1.5636360329510388
how can one figure symbolize both?   Christianity declares that    1.5127085093302464
in the life and death of Jesus Christ the unique and the universal    1.67495327387791
concur. Perhaps no church father saw this concurrence of the unique    1.6065767145351917
and the universal as clearly, or formulated it as precisely, as Irenaeus.    1.6432600607208703
To be the Savior and the Lord, Jesus Christ has to be a historical    1.7026049541338664
individual with a biography all his own; he dare not be a cosmic    1.67495327387791
aeon that swoops to earth for a while but never identifies itself    1.6432600607208703
with man's history. Yet this utterly individual historical person    1.5127085093302464
must also contain within himself the common history of mankind. His    1.6065767145351917
history is his alone, yet each man must recognize his own history in    1.67495327387791
it. His death is his alone, yet each man can see his own death in the    1.748515906000203
crucifixion of Jesus. Each man can identify himself with the history    1.6065767145351917
and the death of Jesus Christ because Jesus Christ has identified    1.6065767145351917
himself with human history and human death, coming as the head of a    1.67495327387791
new humanity. Not a circle, then, nor a straight line, but a spiral    1.67495327387791
represents the shape of death as Irenaeus sees it; for a spiral has    1.67495327387791
motion as well as recurrence. As represented by a spiral, history may,    1.6432600607208703
in some sense, be said to repeat itself; yet each historical event    1.6432600607208703
remains unique. Christ is both unique and universal.   The first    1.5636360329510388
turn of the spiral is the primeval history of humanity in Adam. As    1.67495327387791
Origen interprets the end of history on the basis of its beginning,    1.6432600607208703
so Irenaeus portrays the story of Adam on the basis of the story of    1.7026049541338664
Christ. "Whence, then, comes the substance of the first man? From    1.6065767145351917
God's Will and Wisdom, and from virgin earth. For 'God had    1.6065767145351917
not rained', says the Scripture, before man was made, 'and there    1.6065767145351917
was no man to till the earth'. From this earth, then, while it was    1.7026049541338664
still virgin God took dust and fashioned the man, the beginning of humanity".    1.67495327387791
Irenaeus does not regard Adam and Eve merely as private    1.5636360329510388
individuals, but as universal human beings, who were and are all of humanity.    1.67495327387791
Adam and Eve were perfect, not in the sense that they possessed    1.6432600607208703
perfection, but in the sense that they were capable of development    1.6065767145351917
toward perfection. They were, in fact, children. Irenaeus does not    1.5636360329510388
claim pre-existence for the human soul; therefore there is no need for    1.6432600607208703
him, as there is for Origen, to identify existence itself with the    1.6432600607208703
fall. Existence is created and willed by God and is not the consequence    1.67495327387791
of a pre-existent rebellion or of a cosmic descent from eternity    1.6065767145351917
into history. Historical existence is a created good.   The biblical    1.5636360329510388
symbol for this affirmation is expressed in the words: "So    1.5636360329510388
God created man in his own image; in the similitude of God he created    1.7026049541338664

[of    1.0
God] in his formation, but not receiving the similitude [of God]    1.6065767145351917

a man a man and not an oyster; the similitude of God, by contrast,    1.7026049541338664
is that which makes a man a child of God and not merely a rational creature.    1.748515906000203
Recent research on Irenaeus, however, makes it evident that    1.5127085093302464

Therefore Irenaeus describes man's creation as follows:    1.3761581156320553
"So that the man should not have thoughts of grandeur, and become lifted    1.67495327387791

These conditions man did not keep, and thus he became mortal;    1.6065767145351917

number at the center of the <Lo Shu>, and the interrelation    1.6065767145351917

about the world view of the Old Chinese, which they felt they    1.6432600607208703
saw expressed in it.   The Chinese world view during the Han dynasty,    1.6432600607208703
when the <Lo Shu> seems to have been at the height of its    1.67495327387791

and Five-Elements School, which was traditionally founded by Tsou    1.5127085093302464

<T'ien>- as a natural force, or in the personification of a Supreme    1.6432600607208703
Sky-god- governing all things by means of a process called the    1.6065767145351917

which can be roughly interpreted as "the Order of the Universe"    1.6065767145351917
or "the Universal Way". Heaven, acting through the Tao,    1.5127085093302464
expressed itself by means of the workings of two basic principles,    1.6065767145351917
the Yin and the Yang. The Yang, or male principle, was the source    1.67495327387791
of light, heat, and dynamic vitality, associated with the Sun; while    1.6065767145351917
the Yin, or female principle, flourished in darkness, cold, and quiet    1.6065767145351917

principles influenced all things, and in varying combinations they were    1.5636360329510388
present in everything.   We have already seen that odd numbers    1.5636360329510388
were considered as being Yang, while the even numbers were Yin, so    1.6432600607208703
that the eight outer numbers of the <Lo Shu> represented these two    1.6432600607208703
principles in balanced equilibrium around the axial center. During    1.5127085093302464

9, Huo-Shan in Anhwei, which was then the South Sacred Mountain.    1.6065767145351917
For the rivers, the 4 represented the Huai, to the (then) Southeast;    1.6432600607208703
the 2, the San Kiang (three rivers) in the (then) Southwest;    1.6065767145351917
the 8, the Chi in the Northeast; and the 6, the (upper) Yellow River    1.7026049541338664
in the Northwest.   Note that by Western standards this    1.5127085093302464

about him, but with these two qualifications, the statement stands.    1.5636360329510388

MUCH MORE than shelter, housing symbolizes social status,    1.4513752902486308
a sense of "belonging", acceptance within a given group or neighborhood,    1.6065767145351917
identification with particular cultural values and social institutions,    1.4513752902486308
feelings of pride and worth, aspirations and hopes basic to    1.5636360329510388
human well-being. For almost one-sixth of the national population discrimination    1.5636360329510388
in the free selection of residence casts a considerable shadow    1.5636360329510388
upon these values assumed as self-evident by most Americans.   1.5127085093302464
Few business groups in recent years have come under heavier pressure    1.6065767145351917

This pressure has urged re-evaluation of the assumptions underlying    1.5127085093302464
their professional ethics; it has sought new sympathy for the human    1.6065767145351917
aspirations of racial minority groups in this country. It is not surprising    1.6432600607208703
that, as spokesman for real estate interests, the National Association    1.5636360329510388
of Real Estate Boards (~NAREB) and its local associations    1.5127085093302464

How does the local realtor see himself in the context of housing    1.6432600607208703
restrictions based on race, religion or ethnic attachment? What    1.5127085093302464
does he conceive his role to be in this area of social unrest? What    1.7026049541338664

change? What social, ethical and theological insights can the    1.5127085093302464

Recently, a group of the faculty at Wesleyan University's Public    1.5636360329510388
Affairs Center sought some answers to these questions. Several    1.5127085093302464

insights to bear upon the question of discrimination in housing    1.5636360329510388

THE LYRIC BEAUTIES of Schubert's <Trout> Quintet-    1.3761581156320553
its elemental rhythms and infectious melodies- make it a source    1.5636360329510388
of pure pleasure for almost all music listeners. But for students of    1.6432600607208703
musical forms and would-be classifiers, the work presents its problems.    1.5636360329510388
Since it requires only five players, it would seem to fall into the    1.67495327387791
category of chamber music- yet it calls for a double bass, an instrument    1.67495327387791
generally regarded as symphonic. Moreover, the piece is written    1.5127085093302464
in five movements, rather than the conventional four of most quintets,    1.6065767145351917
and this gives the opus a serenade or divertimento flavor.   The    1.6065767145351917
many and frequent performances of the <Trout> serve to emphasize    1.5636360329510388
the dual nature of its writing. Some renditions are of symphonic dimensions,    1.6432600607208703
with the contrabass given free rein. Other interpretations present    1.5127085093302464
the music as an essentially intimate creation. In these readings,    1.5636360329510388
the double bass is either kept discreetly in the background, or it    1.6432600607208703
is dressed in clown's attire- the musical equivalent of a bull in    1.6432600607208703
a china shop. Recently I was struck anew by the divergent approaches,    1.6432600607208703
when in the course of one afternoon and evening I listened to no fewer    1.7026049541338664
than ten different performances. The occasion for this marathon:    1.5127085093302464
Angel's long-awaited reissue in its "Great Recordings of the    1.5127085093302464
Century" series of the Schnabel-Pro Arte version. Let me say at    1.6065767145351917
the outset that the music sounded as sparkling on the last playing as    1.67495327387791
it did on the first.   Whether considered alone or in relation    1.6065767145351917
to other editions, ~COLH 40 is a document of prime importance.    1.6065767145351917
Artur Schnabel was one of the greatest Schubert-Beethoven-Mozart    1.4513752902486308
players of all time, and any commentary of his on this repertory is valuable.    1.7026049541338664
But Schnabel was a great teacher in addition to being a great    1.6432600607208703
performer, and the fact that four of the ten versions I listened to    1.67495327387791

MUST records always sound like records?   From the beginning    1.5127085093302464
of commercial recording, new discs purported to be indistinguishable    1.5127085093302464
from The Real Thing have regularly been put in circulation. Seen    1.6065767145351917
in perspective, many of these releases have a genuine claim to be milestones.    1.67495327387791
Although lacking absolute verisimilitude, they supply the    1.3761581156320553
ear and the imagination with all necessary materials for re-creation    1.5636360329510388
of the original. On the basis of what they give us we can know how the    1.748515906000203
young Caruso sang, appreciate the distinctive qualities of <Parsifal>    1.5127085093302464
under Karl Muck's baton, or sense the type of ensemble Toscanini    1.6065767145351917
created in his years with the New York Philharmonic.   Since    1.5636360329510388
the concept of high fidelity became important some dozen years ago,    1.6065767145351917
the claims of technical improvements have multiplied tenfold. In many    1.5636360329510388
cases the revolutionary production has offered no more than sensational    1.5636360329510388
effects: the first hearing was fascinating and the second disillusioning    1.5636360329510388
as the gap between sound and substance became clearer. Other    1.5636360329510388
innovations with better claims to musical interest survived rehearing    1.5127085093302464
to acquire in time the status of classics. If we return to them today,    1.7026049541338664
we have no difficulty spotting their weaknesses but we find them    1.6065767145351917
still pleasing.   Records sound like records because they provide    1.5127085093302464
a different sort of experience than live music. This difference is    1.6065767145351917
made up of many factors. Some of them are obvious, such as the fact    1.7026049541338664
that we associate recorded and live music with our reponses and behavior    1.6432600607208703
in different types of environments and social settings. (Music often    1.5636360329510388
sounds best to me when I can dress informally and sit in something    1.67495327387791
more comfortable than a theatre seat.) From the technical standpoint,    1.5636360329510388
records differ from live music to the degree that they fail to convey    1.67495327387791
the true color, texture, complexity, range, intensity, pulse, and pitch    1.5636360329510388
of the original. Any alteration of one of these factors is distortion,    1.6432600607208703
although we generally use that word only for effects so pronounced    1.6065767145351917
that they can be stated quantitatively on the basis of standard tests.    1.6432600607208703
Yet it is the accumulation of distortion, the fitting together of    1.6065767145351917
fractional bits until the total reaches the threshold of our awareness,    1.6065767145351917
that makes records sound like records. The sound may be good;    1.6065767145351917
but if you know The Real Thing, you know that what you are hearing    1.7026049541338664
is only a clever imitation.   Command's new Brahms Second is    1.5636360329510388
a major effort to make a record that sounds like a real orchestra rather    1.7026049541338664
than a copy of one. Like the recent <Scheherazade> from London    1.6065767145351917
(HIGH FIDELITY, Sept& 1961), it is successful because emphasis    1.5127085093302464
has been placed on good musical and engineering practices rather than    1.6065767145351917
on creating sensational effects. Because of this, only those with    1.5636360329510388
truly fine equipment will be able to appreciate the exact degree of the    1.67495327387791
engineers' triumph.   The easiest way to describe this release    1.5127085093302464
is to say that it reproduces an interesting and effective Steinberg    1.6065767145351917
performance with minimal alteration of its musical values. The engineering    1.5636360329510388
as such never obtrudes upon your consciousness. The effect of    1.5636360329510388
the recording is very open and natural, with the frequency emphasis    1.6065767145351917
exactly what you would expect from a live performance. This absence of    1.6432600607208703
peaky highs and beefed-up bass not only produces greater fidelity, but    1.6065767145351917
it eliminates listener fatigue. A contributing factor is the perspective,    1.5636360329510388
the uniform aesthetic distance which is maintained. The orchestra    1.5127085093302464
is far enough away from you that you miss the bow scrapes, valve    1.67495327387791
clicks, and other noises incidental to playing. Yet you feel the orchestra    1.6432600607208703
is near at hand, and the individual instruments have the same firm    1.6432600607208703
presence associated with listening from a good seat in an acoustically    1.6065767145351917
perfect hall. Command has achieved the ideal amount of reverberation.    1.5636360329510388
The music is always allowed the living space needed to attain its    1.6432600607208703
full sonority; yet the hall never intrudes as a quasi-performer. The    1.6065767145351917
timbre remains that of the instruments unclouded by resonance.   1.5127085093302464
All of this would be wasted, of course, if the performance lacked    1.6432600607208703
authority and musical distinction. For me it has more of both elements    1.6432600607208703
than the majority of its competitors. Steinberg seems to have gone    1.6065767145351917
directly back to the score, discounting tradition, and has built his    1.6065767145351917
performance on the intention to reproduce as faithfully as possible exactly    1.6065767145351917
what Brahms set down on paper.   Those accustomed to broader,    1.5636360329510388

strongly when they hear this one. Without losing the distinctive undertow    1.6065767145351917
of Brahmsian rhythm, the pacing is firm and the over-all performance    1.6065767145351917
has a tightly knit quality that makes for maximum cumulative effect.    1.6065767145351917
The <Presto ma non assai> of the first trio of the scherzo is    1.67495327387791
taken literally and may shock you, as the real <Allegro con spirito>    1.6432600607208703
of the finale is likely to bring you to your feet. In the end, however,    1.7269387314284994

the effect of the whole orchestra bursting into song.   The    1.5636360329510388
engineering provides exactly the support needed for such a result. Too    1.6065767145351917
many records seem to reduce a work of symphonic complexity to a melody    1.67495327387791
and its accompaniment. The Command technique invites you to listen    1.5636360329510388
to the depth of the orchestration. Your ear takes you into the ensemble,    1.67495327387791
and you may well become aware of instrumental details which previously    1.6065767145351917
were apparent only in the score. It is this sort of experience    1.6432600607208703
that makes the concept of high fidelity of real musical significance    1.6065767145351917
for the home music listener.    1.1606783668269585

of its scope since Feyer's four-sided ~LP edition of 1958 for    1.6065767145351917
Angel), this set is, I'm afraid, likely to provide more horrid fascination    1.6432600607208703

THE design of a mechanical interlocking frame is much like a mechanical    1.6432600607208703
puzzle, but once understood, the principles can be applied to    1.5636360329510388
any track and signal arrangement. In the frame are two sets of bars    1.67495327387791
which interact with each other to prevent the operator from making dangerous    1.6432600607208703
moves. The main set of bars are the "tappets" and one tappet    1.6432600607208703
is connected to each lever. If the lever is pulled to clear a signal    1.7026049541338664
or move a switch, the tappet moves a short distance lengthwise at    1.6432600607208703
the same time.   Close behind the plane of the tappets are the locking    1.67495327387791
bars. These can also move a short distance but at right angles    1.6432600607208703
to the tappets. The number of locking bars required depends on how many    1.67495327387791
false moves must be prevented.   In the sides of the tappets    1.6065767145351917
are notches with sloping sides, and connection between the tappets and    1.6065767145351917
locking bars consist of cams called "dogs". Two or more dogs are    1.6432600607208703
mounted on each locking bar. These slide into and out of the notches    1.67495327387791
in the tappets as the tappets are moved, locking and unlocking them.   1.6432600607208703
Here's how the scheme works: Suppose the operator pulls    1.5127085093302464
the lever to clear a particular signal. This also pulls the tappet connected    1.67495327387791
to the particular lever and forces any dogs seated in the notches    1.6432600607208703
to the side, thus moving one or more locking bars. The dogs on the    1.7026049541338664
other ends of these locking bars are thus forced into notches in other    1.67495327387791
tappets. By this scheme, pulling one signal to clear locks all the    1.6432600607208703
other switch and signal levers in safe positions until the first signal    1.6432600607208703
is again restored to normal.   Interlocking signals are normally    1.5127085093302464
at stop or "red" position, and a lever must be pulled to "clear"    1.67495327387791
the signal. This is not necessarily to green, however, for in    1.6065767145351917
some situations only a yellow indication is given to a train to let it    1.7026049541338664
into the "plant".   There are other basic rules. A turnout    1.5636360329510388
may have two levers, one to actually move the switch points, the other    1.67495327387791
to lock the points. A signal cannot be cleared until all the related    1.67495327387791
turnouts are properly thrown <and> locked. Such locks are nearly    1.5636360329510388
always used where the switch points "face" oncoming traffic. The    1.5636360329510388
lock insures that the points are thrown all the way with no chance that    1.7026049541338664
a wheel flange will snag on a partly thrown point. If the points aren't    1.7026049541338664
thrown all the way, the turnout cannot be locked, and in turn,    1.6432600607208703
the signal cannot be cleared. Generally, these locks on turnouts are    1.6065767145351917
called "facing point locks".   Figs& 1-6 show typical arrangements    1.5127085093302464
of track and signals. Each diagram is accompanied by a "dog    1.6065767145351917
chart", a list of the levers that show which other levers any particular    1.67495327387791
lever will lock if pulled. The lines connecting the wedge-shaped    1.5636360329510388
dogs represent the locking bars at right angles to the tappet bars.   1.6432600607208703
By studying the track-signal diagrams you'll note several    1.4513752902486308
other details. Derails- mechanical track devices that actually guide    1.5127085093302464
the wheels off the rails if a train passes a "stop" signal- are    1.67495327387791
used in many instances. "Home" signals have two blades. The blacked-in    1.6065767145351917
blades indicate a fixed aspect- the blade does not move. As    1.6065767145351917
an engineer approaches the plant the position of the home signal    1.6065767145351917
is seen in advance when he passes the "distant" signal located    1.6065767145351917
beyond the limits of the interlocking plant. In some low-speed situations,    1.6065767145351917
the distant signal is fixed at caution. In other instances where    1.6065767145351917
there is no automatic block signaling, the distant has only green    1.6065767145351917
and yellow aspects.   So much for the prototype.   The interlocking    1.5636360329510388

Scientists say that the world and everything in it are based on    1.6432600607208703
mathematics. Without math the men who are continually seeking the causes    1.6065767145351917
of and the reasons for the many things that make the world go 'round    1.7026049541338664
would not have any means of analyzing, standardizing, and communicating    1.5636360329510388
the things they discover and learn. Math and the formulas that    1.6065767145351917
allow it to be applied to different problems are, therefore, essential    1.6065767145351917
to any scientific endeavor.   Hot rodding is a science. It's    1.5636360329510388
not a science as involved as determining what makes the earth rotate    1.6432600607208703
on its axis or building a rocket or putting a satellite into orbit    1.67495327387791
but it is, nevertheless, a science. But because science is based on mathematics    1.67495327387791
doesn't mean that a hot rodder must necessarily be a mathematician.    1.6065767145351917
A guy can be an active and successful hot rodder for years    1.6432600607208703
without becoming even remotely involved with mathematical problems;    1.4513752902486308
however, he will have a clearer understanding of what he is doing and    1.67495327387791
the chances are he will be more successful if he understands the few    1.67495327387791
formulas that apply to rodding.   A mathematical formula is nothing    1.5636360329510388
more than a pattern for solving a specific problem. It places the    1.6432600607208703
various factors involved in the problem in their correct order in relation    1.6432600607208703
to each other so that the influence of factors on each other can    1.67495327387791
be computed.   The first step in using a formula is to insert the    1.67495327387791
numerical values of the factors involved in their correct positions    1.5636360329510388
in the formula. This changes the formula to an "equation". The    1.6065767145351917
equation is used for the mathematical process of solving the problem.   1.6065767145351917
Equations for rodding formulas are not complicated. They involve    1.5127085093302464
only simple mathematics that are taught in grammar school arithmetic    1.5636360329510388
classes. However, it is essential that the various mathematical symbols    1.5636360329510388
used in the equations be understood so that the mathematical processes    1.6065767145351917
can be done properly and in their correct order. They indicate    1.6065767145351917
simple division, multiplication, subtraction, and addition.   The    1.3761581156320553
symbol for division is a straight line that separates two numbers    1.6065767145351917
placed one above the other. The lower number is always divided into the    1.67495327387791
upper number: **f   The symbol for multiplication is "~@".    1.4513752902486308
It is used to separate two or more numbers in a row. For example:    1.7026049541338664
**f Numbers to be multiplied together may be multiplied in any    1.6065767145351917
order. The result will be the same regardless of the order used.   1.6432600607208703
The symbol for subtraction is the standard minus sign. This is    1.6065767145351917
nothing more than a dash. It separates two or more numbers. The number    1.67495327387791
on the right of the symbol is always subtracted from the number on    1.67495327387791
the left of the symbol. For example: **f When more than two figures    1.67495327387791
are separated by subtraction symbols the subtraction must be carried    1.5636360329510388
out from the left to right if the result is to be correct. For example,    1.7269387314284994
for the problem **f, 10 from 25 equals 15, then 6 from 15 equals    1.7026049541338664
9.   Addition is indicated by the ~+ symbol. The symbol is    1.5636360329510388
used to separate two or more numbers. For example: **f Numbers separated    1.6432600607208703
by addition symbols may be placed in any order.   When solving    1.6065767145351917
an equation that involves division as well as other steps, do all    1.6432600607208703
the division steps first    1.0
to reduce those parts of the equation to their    1.5127085093302464
numerical value. Multiplication, subtraction, and addition can then    1.4513752902486308
be accomplished as they appear in the equation by starting at the left    1.67495327387791
end of the equation and working toward the right. Completing the    1.6065767145351917
division first also includes those division parts that require multiplication,    1.5636360329510388
subtraction, or addition steps: **f This would be reduced    1.5127085093302464
by multiplying 8 times 6 and then dividing the product by 12. This part    1.7026049541338664
of the equation would then become 4.   For use in formulas, fractions    1.6432600607208703
should be converted to their decimal equivalents. The easiest    1.5127085093302464
way to do this is with a conversion chart. Charts for this purpose    1.67495327387791

Shortening the results in this manner will not have any detrimental    1.6065767145351917
effect on the accuracy of the final result.   Some formulas    1.5636360329510388
contain "constants". A constant is a number that remains the same    1.6065767145351917
regardless of the other numbers used in the formula and the resultant    1.6432600607208703
equation. It is a number without which the equation cannot be solved    1.6432600607208703
correctly.   Rodding formulas apply to many phases of the sport.    1.5636360329510388
The answers they give can often pave the way to performance increases    1.6432600607208703
and,    1.0
quite often, are necessary for completing entry blanks for different    1.5636360329510388
events. When it is needed, one formula is as important as another.    1.6432600607208703
However, some formulas are used more than others. We'll take    1.5636360329510388
them in the general order of their popularity.    1.4513752902486308
A rodder should be able to compute the displacement of his engine.    1.6432600607208703
Displacement is sometimes referred to as "swept volume". Most    1.5127085093302464
entry blanks for competitive events require engine displacement information    1.5127085093302464

displacement so that changes in it resulting from boring and stroking    1.6065767145351917

are the bore diameter of the engine's cylinders, the length of the    1.6432600607208703
piston stroke, the number of cylinders in the engine, and a constant.    1.6432600607208703
The constant is .7854, which is one-quarter of 3.1416, another constant    1.6065767145351917
known as "pi". Pi is used in formulas concerned with the dimensions    1.6432600607208703
of circles.   Actually, the engine displacement formula is    1.4513752902486308

with an added factor that represents the number of cylinders in the    1.6432600607208703
engine. The cross-sectional area of the cylinders is determined and    1.5636360329510388

A cylinder's compression ratio    1.0
is computed by comparing the cylinder's volume, or its displacement,    1.5636360329510388

around the chamber before they will flow out of the chamber.   1.6065767145351917

The average reader of this magazine owns more than one gun (we    1.6432600607208703
ran a survey to find out) but he's always on the lookout for new and    1.7269387314284994
better arms. He's more than a reader of outdoor articles; he's    1.6065767145351917
a real hunter and shooter, eager to improve his sport. Well, if you're    1.67495327387791
that kind of sportsman we're here to help you. You've probably    1.6065767145351917
given a lot of Christmas-season thought to the guns in your rack,    1.6432600607208703
but it's not easy to decide on a new one. You still have time to    1.7269387314284994
drop a few hints about the gifts you'd appreciate most; the time    1.6432600607208703
to decide on them is now. As a Christmas service, I've taken a close    1.7026049541338664
look at this year's crop of new models. Here they are, with my    1.67495327387791
comments and judgments. Read on, take your pick- and start dropping    1.6065767145351917
those hints.   First on my own list would be two arms- a rifle    1.67495327387791
and a handgun- that qualify as new in the strictest sense.    1.6065767145351917
For me, a changed barrel length or an improved stock doesn't constitute    1.6432600607208703
a truly new design. Such modifications are all for the best but    1.6432600607208703
it takes something as different as a Deerstalker or a Jet to change    1.67495327387791
arms-making concepts.   Bill Ruger's long-awaited Deerstalker    1.2818970554302986
(under $110) is a new rifle action in a caliber that upsets all the    1.7026049541338664
modern theory of high-velocity fans; it's a short, light, quick-handling,    1.5636360329510388
fast-firing little timber gun designed to push a heavy slug    1.5636360329510388
at modest velocity but with lots of killing power and ample range for    1.67495327387791
our most popular big game- whitetail.   Ruger reports that    1.5127085093302464
on his recent African safari the little .44 Magnum cartridge was a    1.6432600607208703
real work horse. Small antelope were generally grassed with one shot,    1.6065767145351917
and the .44 Magnum carbine also bagged reedbuck, kob and wart hog with    1.67495327387791
deadly efficiency; these are fairly large, tough animals.    1.4513752902486308
The deadliness of the .44 Magnum in a rifle comes as no surprise to    1.7026049541338664
me. At least five years ago, Tom Robinson of Marlin made up an over/under    1.7026049541338664
double rifle for me in this caliber, using the now defunct Model    1.6432600607208703
90 action in 20-gauge size. After figuring out how to regulate the    1.6432600607208703
barrels so that they shot to the same point of impact, we fired this    1.7026049541338664
little 20-inch-barrel job on my home range and in Marlin's underground    1.6065767145351917
test gallery. We quickly ran into the same trouble that plagued Bill    1.6432600607208703
Ruger in his first experiments: Three or four bullets would be    1.6065767145351917
placed well in a six-inch bull at 100 yards and then, unaccountably,    1.6432600607208703
one could stray far out of the group.   Ruger learned that this    1.6432600607208703
was because the higher velocity achieved in a long barrel was upsetting    1.6432600607208703
the shape of the unjacketed revolver bullet. The new, jacketed slug    1.6065767145351917
in .44 Magnum corrected this. But even without jacketed bullets, I    1.6065767145351917
had enough faith in my double to take it on an opening-day deer hunt    1.7026049541338664
that first year. Within half an hour I jumped a six-point buck that    1.67495327387791
hop-skipped through a rhododendron thicket, and I caught him just behind    1.6065767145351917
the left foreleg at 60 yards. He moved only about 30 feet after    1.67495327387791
the 240-grain slug hit him- and this was after the bullet had passed    1.67495327387791
through a sapling.   Three more deer have fallen to this same    1.6065767145351917
gun, and all were one-shot kills. My double was made with standard-weight    1.6432600607208703
revolver barrels (before cutting to revolver length), and although    1.5127085093302464
it compares well in other respects, it's considerably heavier than    1.5636360329510388
the Deerstalker, which only scales about 6-1/2 pounds.   If ever    1.5636360329510388
a rifle met the needs of the whitetail hunter, this is it. The Deerstalker    1.7026049541338664
points with the ease, speed and precision of a fine imported    1.6065767145351917
double shotgun, and its trigger pull is light and sharp. The 240-grain    1.6432600607208703
bullet leaves the muzzle at 1,850 ~fps, which gives it all the smash    1.67495327387791
needed at woods ranges. With five shots at the immediate command    1.6065767145351917
of the hunter's trigger finger, the gun and load are a deadly combination.   1.67495327387791
The second really new development this year was a revolver    1.5636360329510388
handling a different sort of varmint load- the .22 Remington Jet    1.6065767145351917
Magnum Center Fire. At present it's available in one model, the    1.6065767145351917
fine and familiar Smith + Wesson Magnum revolver (about $110),    1.5127085093302464
long a top-quality handgun among target arms. The velocity of this .22-caliber,    1.6432600607208703
40-grain bullet is rated at a very hot 2,460 ~fps, and it's    1.6432600607208703
the flattest shooting of any revolver cartridge, with a mid-range    1.5636360329510388
rise of about an inch over a 100-yard range. This is a varmint load,    1.7026049541338664
pure and simple; it's much too explosive for small edible game.    1.6065767145351917
It can cut a red squirrel neatly in two or burst a crow into a flurry    1.748515906000203
of feathers.   The most intriguing aspect of the ~S+W Magnum    1.5636360329510388
chambered for the new Jet is that it can also fire standard .22 rim-fires    1.7026049541338664
by means of adapter sleeves in the chambers. You may therefore    1.6065767145351917
convert the gun into a small-game and plinking arm, although the difference    1.6432600607208703
in the point of impact (Jet vs& rim-fire) can be somewhat disconcerting.    1.6432600607208703
The accuracy of the Jet cartridge is fine; I tested    1.5636360329510388
it in my scoped ~S+W and it was good enough to allow me to hit a    1.748515906000203
chuck with every shot at 100 yards if I did my part by holding the handgun    1.748515906000203
steadily.    1.0
The fact that the Deerstalker    1.1606783668269585
and the Jet were the only completely new designs this year doesn't    1.6432600607208703
mean that 1961 didn't see changes in models, actions and calibers.    1.6065767145351917
Aside from the Ruger carbine, a number of hunting rifles have been    1.6432600607208703
introduced for the first time. Here are the brands (in alphabetical    1.6065767145351917
order) and the new models.   Newcomers to the American hunter    1.5636360329510388
are the Browning group of bolt-action, high-power rifles. They have    1.5636360329510388
fine ~FN actions and a better-than-average finish on both the metal    1.6065767145351917
and the stock wood. Barrel weights vary sensibly with the various    1.6065767145351917
calibers available, and these include the standard bores (about $165)    1.5636360329510388
plus the Magnums (around $170); the latter include the .264, .300    1.6065767145351917
~H+H, .338, .375 and .458. Shotgun-type rubber recoil pads are standard    1.6065767145351917
on all of the Magnums except the .264. Stock designs are excellent    1.6432600607208703
for use with scopes.   Colt's center-fire 1961 rifles are    1.5127085093302464
all made with Sako actions, regardless of caliber. The .222's have    1.6065767145351917
the short action; the .243 and .308, the medium action, and the .270,    1.67495327387791
**f and the Magnums, the long action (about $135 for the Standard    1.6432600607208703
Coltsman and $200 for the Custom version). Previously, ~FN actions    1.5636360329510388
were used for the larger cartridges.   High standard has    1.5127085093302464
introduced a .22 auto, the Sport-King, in two grades- field and special    1.6432600607208703
(less than $45 and just over $45, respectively). It's a streamlined    1.6065767145351917

LIVERY STABLE- J& VERNON, PROP"& Coaching had declined    1.4513752902486308
considerably by 1905, but the sign was still there, near the old    1.6432600607208703
Wells Fargo building in San Francisco, creaking in the fog as it    1.6432600607208703
had for thirty years. John Vernon had had all the patronage he cared    1.67495327387791
for- he had prospered, but he could not retire from horsedom. Coaching    1.6432600607208703
was in his blood. He had two interests in life: the pleasures    1.6432600607208703
of the table and driving. Twice a week he drove his tallyho over the    1.7026049541338664
Santa Cruz road, upland and through the redwood forest, with orchards    1.6065767145351917
below him at one hand, and glimpses of the Pacific at the other. The    1.7026049541338664
journey back he made along the coast road, traveling hell-for-leather,    1.5636360329510388
every lantern of the tallyho ablaze.   The southward route    1.5127085093302464
was the classic run in California, and the most fashionable. His patronage    1.6432600607208703
on this stretch was made up largely of San Franciscans- regulars,    1.6065767145351917
most of them, and trenchermen like himself. They did not complain    1.6065767145351917
at the inhuman hour of starting (seven in the morning), nor of the    1.67495327387791
tariff, which was reasonable since it covered everything but the tobacco.    1.6065767145351917
Breakfast was at the Palace Hotel, luncheon was somewhere in the    1.6065767145351917
mountain forest, and dinner was either at Boulder Creek or at Santa    1.6432600607208703
Cruz.   Gazing too long at the scenery could be tiring, so    1.6065767145351917
halts were contrived between meals. Then the Chinese hostler, who rode    1.6065767145351917
with Vernon on the box, would break open a hamper and produce filets    1.67495327387791
of smoked bass or sturgeon, sandwiches, pickled eggs, and a rum sangaree    1.6432600607208703
to be heated over a spirit lamp.   In spring and in autumn    1.6432600607208703
the run was made for a group of botanists which included an old friend    1.7026049541338664
of mine. They gathered roots, bulbs, odd ferns, leaves, and bits of    1.6432600607208703
resin from the rare Santa Lucia fir, which exists only on a forty-five    1.67495327387791
mile strip on the westerly side of these mountains. In the Spanish    1.6432600607208703
days Franciscan monks roamed here to collect the resin for incense.    1.6065767145351917
It yields a fragrance as Orphic as that of the pastilles of Malabar.    1.67495327387791
Vernon was serviceable on the botanical field trips, but he could    1.6065767145351917

My friend often breakfasted with Vernon on the morning of the regular    1.6432600607208703

Sure, for the most of us, a frankfurter is the favorite. A    1.6432600607208703

_NOTE:_ Directions are written for those who have had previous    1.5636360329510388
experience in making pottery. Instructions for preparing clay, drying,    1.5127085093302464

Basic pottery    1.0
studio equipment. Wooden butter molds and cookie presses.    1.4513752902486308
Ceramic modeling clay: red, white or buff. Stoneware clay    1.5127085093302464
for tiles. Glazes, one-stroke ceramic colors, stains, cones as indicated    1.5636360329510388
in the individual instructions.    1.0
Use    1.0
well-wedged clay,    1.0
free of air bubbles and pliable enough to bend without    1.5636360329510388
cracking. Clean wooden molds and presses thoroughly; they must be    1.5636360329510388
free of oil, wax and dust. _PRESSING DESIGNS:_ The size of wooden    1.6432600607208703
mold will determine the amount of clay needed. Roll clay to thickness    1.6432600607208703
indicated in individual instructions. Whenever possible, use the    1.4513752902486308
wooden mold as a pattern for cutting clay. When mold has more than one    1.7026049541338664
design cavity, make individual paper patterns. Place mold or paper    1.5636360329510388
pattern on rolled clay and cut clay by holding knife in vertical position    1.67495327387791
(cut more pieces than required for project to make allowance for    1.6065767145351917
defects; experiment with defects for decoration techniques of glazes    1.5127085093302464
and colors). Place the cut clay piece loosely over the carved cavity    1.6432600607208703
design side of wooden mold. To obtain clear impression of mold, press    1.6432600607208703
clay gently but firmly into mold cavity, starting at center and working    1.6432600607208703
to outer edges. Trim excess clay away from outer edges. Check thickness    1.6432600607208703
of clay and build up thin areas by moistening surface with a little    1.67495327387791
water and adding small pieces of clay. Be sure to press the additional    1.67495327387791
clay firmly into place without locking in air bubbles. Allow    1.5636360329510388
project to stand for about five minutes (if wooden press mold is a good    1.7026049541338664
antique, do not leave clay in too long as the dampness may cause mold    1.7026049541338664
to crack).   To release clay from mold, place hands in a cupped    1.6432600607208703
position around project; gently lift the edge on far side, then continue    1.6432600607208703
to release edge completely around mold. Slight tapping on the    1.5636360329510388
underside of mold will help release the clay, but too much agitation will    1.67495327387791
cause the clay to become soft and will interfere with removal of clay    1.67495327387791
from mold. Place a piece of plaster wall board or plaster bat on    1.67495327387791
clay and reverse bat, clay and mold in one action. This will prevent    1.67495327387791
the clay from twisting or bending, causing warping when fired. Place    1.6065767145351917
project on table and carefully lift the mold off. Study surface of clay    1.67495327387791
for defects or desired corrections. If clay is slightly out of shape,    1.6432600607208703
square straight sides with guide sticks or rulers pressed against    1.5636360329510388
opposite sides, or smooth round pieces with damp fingers. if the background    1.6432600607208703
of design is too smooth, or you wish to create a wood-grained effect,    1.67495327387791
it may be added at this time with a dull tool such as the handle    1.7269387314284994
of a fine paintbrush. Make slight, smooth grooves rather than cuts    1.6065767145351917
for the texture (cuts could cause air pockets under the glaze creating    1.6432600607208703
pinholes or craters in the glaze during firing). Leave the clay on    1.6432600607208703
plaster board to dry slowly, covered lightly with a loose piece of plastic    1.67495327387791
or cloth to prevent warping.    1.1606783668269585

HOTEI is 23 feet long with an 8-1/2-foot beam and every inch    1.6432600607208703
a family boat. Menfolk can ride in the forward cockpit where the    1.6432600607208703
helmsman has a clear view. Youngsters can sleep or amuse themselves    1.6065767145351917
safely in the large cabin which has 5-foot 11-inch headroom, bunks for    1.6432600607208703
three, galley and marine toilet. The gals can sun themselves in the    1.6432600607208703
roomy aft cockpit. All are well distributed, not crowded together near    1.6065767145351917
the stern. And with passenger weight shifted forward, Hotei levels    1.5636360329510388
off for speed under power of a Merc 800. The 80-~hp motor drives    1.67495327387791
her at 25 ~mph with six aboard!   With only two aboard, Hotei    1.6432600607208703
does better than 27    1.0
~mph- and she gives a comfortable ride at this    1.5127085093302464
speed even in a three-foot chop. She also banks into a turn like    1.67495327387791
a fine runabout- not digging in on the outside to throw passengers all    1.67495327387791
over the boat like many a small cabin cruiser. Nor is she a wet boat.    1.7269387314284994
We've been out in five-foot waves and stayed dry.   1.5127085093302464
{A lot of    1.0
thought} went into storage space construction. There's a large compartment    1.5636360329510388
in the forward cockpit for charts and other items. The cabin    1.6065767145351917
has several shelves for small items and storage under the bunks for    1.6432600607208703
water skiis, life jackets, etc&.    1.1606783668269585
The aft cockpit has a **f storage bin    1.4513752902486308
over six feet long that doubles as a seat. On each side of the motor    1.7269387314284994
well there's storage for battery, bumpers, line and spare props with    1.6065767145351917
six-gallon gas tanks below. The well itself is designed to take two    1.6432600607208703
Merc 800's or 500's if you wish and there's room for a 25-gallon    1.67495327387791
long-cruise gas tank below it.   Needless to say, you can't    1.5636360329510388
build Hotei in a couple of weeks. Our building time was slightly    1.6432600607208703
over 400 hours- but the total cost for the hull with Fiberglas bottom,    1.67495327387791

Gator trailer, Model 565, is used to transport the boat to the waterways.    1.67495327387791

you that in mooring and hauling fees in a few years.   All framing    1.67495327387791
in Hotei is one-inch mahogany which, in the dressed state you    1.6065767145351917
buy it, is about the 13/16-inch thickness specified in the drawings. Therefore,    1.6432600607208703
the lumber is bought in planks and ripped to size for battens,    1.6432600607208703
etc&, on a table saw. Besides flathead bronze screws, silicon bronze    1.6065767145351917
Stronghold nails (made by Independent Nail + Packing Co&,    1.4513752902486308

resorcinal glue is used in all the joints.   {Construction}    1.5127085093302464
follows a thorough study of the drawings. Start by laying out the six    1.67495327387791
frames and the transom on a level floor. Draw each outline in a different-color    1.7026049541338664
chalk, one on top of the other. In this way you will be    1.67495327387791
able to detect any obvious mistakes.   The transom frame is made    1.6065767145351917

12 Stronghold nails. After notching it for the keelson, chines and    1.6065767145351917
battens, the half-inch plywood transom is secured to it with glue    1.6065767145351917
and the same type    1.0
nails. All frames are butted at the joints and 3/8-inch plywood gussets    1.6432600607208703
are glued and nailed on each side of each joint, again using the one-inch,    1.7026049541338664
No& 12 nails. The frames are notched only for the keelson    1.6065767145351917
and the chines. If notched for the battens, they would require more work,    1.67495327387791
be weakened and limber holes would have to be bored so that bilge    1.67495327387791

contact with the plywood planking.   The jig is erected after the    1.6065767145351917

All bottom battens are two inches wide. The side ones are a half-inch    1.67495327387791
