With modern techniques of woodworking and the multitude of cutting    1.5636360329510388
tools, fixtures, and attachments available, the drill press has become    1.5636360329510388
a basic home workshop tool. The drill press consists of a vertical    1.6432600607208703
shaft (spindle) which is tapered or threaded on one end to hold a    1.67495327387791
drill chuck, a tubular housing (quill) in which the spindle is mounted,    1.6432600607208703
a head in which the quill is mounted, a feed lever which moves the    1.7026049541338664
quill up or down, a power source, and a movable table upon which the work    1.7269387314284994
is placed. There is often a means of locking the quill and, on larger    1.7026049541338664
presses, the table can be tilted.   The size of the press is    1.6432600607208703
usually expressed in terms of chuck capacity (the maximum diameter tool    1.6065767145351917
shank it will hold) or distance between the spindle center and the    1.6432600607208703
column. A press with an 11 inch capacity lets you drill to the center    1.7026049541338664
of a 22 inch board or circle.   A new radial drill press with    1.67495327387791
a 16 inch capacity has a tilting head that allows drilling to be done    1.7026049541338664
at any angle. The head is mounted on a horizontal arm that swivels on    1.7026049541338664
the supporting column to position the drill bit instead of the work.    1.6432600607208703
The drill press should be leveled and, depending    1.4513752902486308
on whether it is a bench or floor model, bolted securely to a    1.67495327387791
sturdy bench or stand or screwed to the floor with lag or expansion screws.    1.7026049541338664
This will reduce vibration and increase accuracy.   A coat    1.5127085093302464
of paste wax or a rubdown with a piece of wax paper will protect the    1.7269387314284994
polished surface of the table; wiping with a slightly oiled cloth    1.6065767145351917
will discourage rusting of the column and quill. Presses not fitted    1.6065767145351917
with sealed spindle bearings will need a drop of oil now and then in    1.7026049541338664
the lubrication holes in the quill. The rest of the press should be kept    1.7026049541338664
clean by dusting with a clean rag or brush.   Be careful to    1.6432600607208703
keep the drive belt free of oil and grease. Belt tension is adjusted    1.67495327387791
by manipulation of two locking bolts and a movable motor mount. Keep    1.6432600607208703
the belt just tight enough so the pulleys won't slip when pulled by    1.67495327387791
hand; excess tension will only cause undue wear on the motor and spindle    1.67495327387791
bearings. Most drill presses have a quill return spring that raises    1.6065767145351917
the spindle automatically when the feed lever is released and holds    1.6065767145351917
the quill in the raised position. The return spring tension may be    1.6432600607208703
adjusted to suit individual requirements by gripping the spring housing    1.5636360329510388
with a pair of pliers (to prevent the spring from unwinding when it    1.67495327387791
is released), loosening the lock nut or screw, and rotating the housing    1.6432600607208703
until the desired tension is achieved. Turning the housing clockwise    1.5636360329510388
will reduce tension, counter-clockwise will increase it.    1.3761581156320553
Some manufacturers have had the foresight to provide    1.4513752902486308
a socket for the chuck key; otherwise, you'll have to spend    1.6065767145351917
a few minutes to either attach a suitable spring clip somewhere on the    1.67495327387791
press head or fit the key to a length of light chain and fasten to the    1.748515906000203
bottom of the motor mount so that the key is out of the way when not    1.748515906000203
in use.    1.0
Drill speeds are important if you want    1.3761581156320553
a good job. Each cutting tool will operate best at a given speed,    1.67495327387791
depending on the material worked. On most drill presses, it is impossible    1.6432600607208703
to get the exact speed, but you can come close by adjusting the    1.67495327387791
drive belt on the step-cone pulleys. You will find a chart giving the    1.67495327387791
various speed ratios available with your particular drill press somewhere    1.5636360329510388
in the instruction booklet that came with the tool. See the table    1.6432600607208703
on page 34 for exact recommended speeds. Generally, the larger the    1.6065767145351917
tool and the harder the material, the slower the speed.   Feed pressure    1.6432600607208703
is also of major importance. Too much pressure will force the    1.6065767145351917
tool beyond its cutting capacity and result in rough cuts and jammed    1.6432600607208703
or broken tools. Too light a feed, particularly with metal or other hard    1.67495327387791
material, causes overheating of the tool and burning of the cutting    1.6065767145351917
edge. The best results will be obtained by matching the correct speed    1.6432600607208703
with a steady feed pressure that lets the tool cut easily at an even    1.7026049541338664
rate.    1.0
There are numerous types and styles    1.2818970554302986
of tools to drill holes. The most common are the twist drill, the    1.67495327387791
solid center shaft with interchangeable cutting blades, the double spur    1.5636360329510388
bit, and the power wood bit. All will do a good job if sharp, but the    1.748515906000203
twist drills don't cut quite as smoothly as the others, since they    1.6432600607208703
do not have the outlining spurs that sever the fibers before actual    1.6432600607208703
boring starts.   The adjustable fly cutter is very useful for cutting    1.6065767145351917
large diameter holes and can be used to cut exact-size discs by    1.6432600607208703
reversing the cutter blade. Since fly cutters are one sided and not    1.6432600607208703
balanced, they should be used at the slowest speed available, and fed    1.6432600607208703
very slowly to avoid binding. Fly cutters can fool you into putting    1.6432600607208703
your hand too close to the tool, so if you want to avoid nicked fingers,    1.7269387314284994
keep your hands well out of the way.    1.4513752902486308
When drilling all the way through a workpiece, always place a    1.6065767145351917
piece of scrap wood underneath. This will not only protect the work    1.6432600607208703
table, but also assure a clean breakthrough. Another method of assuring    1.6065767145351917
a clean hole is to first drill a small pilot hole all the way through,    1.7269387314284994
then drill half way with the dimensional bit, turn the piece over,    1.6432600607208703
and finish from the other side. In soft woods with pronounced grain,    1.6432600607208703
there is sometimes a tendency for the hole to wander, due to the varying    1.7026049541338664
hardness of the wood. In this case, drilling a small pilot hole or    1.67495327387791
clamping the work will do much to improve accuracy.   When a hole    1.6432600607208703
is to be bored to a predetermined depth, mark the depth on the side    1.7026049541338664
of the stock, then run the bit down so that it is even with the mark.    1.748515906000203
The depth gauge rod can now be set, and any number of holes bored to    1.7269387314284994
exact and identical depth.   1.0

Merrimack River, from the Land of Hon'ble Jonathan Greenleaf,    1.5127085093302464
Esquire, in Newbery, to Deer Island, and from said Island to Salisbury,    1.6432600607208703
would be of very extensive utility, by affording a safe Conveyance    1.6065767145351917
to Carriages, Teams    1.0
and Travellers at all seasons of the year,    1.4513752902486308

DRAW a line across the country at the latitude of lower Pennsylvania.    1.6432600607208703

Home air conditioning has come a long way from the early days    1.6432600607208703
of overcooled theaters and the thermal shock they inflicted. We know    1.6065767145351917
now that a 15-degree differential in temperature is the maximum usually    1.6065767145351917
desirable, and accurate controls assure the comfort we want.    1.5127085093302464
We know, too, that health is never harmed by summer cooling. On the    1.67495327387791
contrary, there are fewer colds and smaller doctor bills. The filtered    1.6065767145351917
air benefits allergies, asthma, sinus, hay fever. Control of temperature    1.5636360329510388
and humidity is a godsend to the aged and the invalid. Heart conditions    1.67495327387791
and high blood pressure escape the stresses brought on by oppressive    1.6065767145351917
heat.   Housekeeping is easier. The cleaner air means    1.4513752902486308
less time spent pushing a vacuum, fewer trips to the dry cleaners, lighter    1.67495327387791
loads for the washing machine. The need for reupholstering, redecorating,    1.5636360329510388
repainting becomes more infrequent. Clothes hold their shape    1.4513752902486308
better, and mildew and rust become almost forgotten words.   It    1.5636360329510388
will improve your disposition. When you're less fatigued, things    1.5127085093302464
just naturally look brighter. The children can have their daytime naps    1.6065767145351917
and hot meals, and be put to bed on schedule in shade-darkened rooms.    1.67495327387791
You'll sleep longer and better, too, awake refreshed and free of    1.6065767145351917
hot weather nerves.   You can forget about screens, and leave the    1.6065767145351917
storm windows up all year around.   Best of all, central air conditioning    1.6432600607208703
is something you can afford. Like its long-lived cousin,    1.5127085093302464
the refrigerator, a conditioner can be expected to last 20 to 25 years    1.67495327387791
or more. That brings its per-year cost down mighty low. _FOR ANY    1.6432600607208703
HOUSE._ No matter what style your home is, ranch, two-story, Colonial    1.6065767145351917
or contemporary, central air conditioning is easily installed. The    1.5127085093302464
equipment won't take up valuable space either. It can go in out-of-the-way    1.6432600607208703
waste space.   But there's no denying that the easiest    1.5127085093302464
and most economical way to get year-'round whole-house air conditioning    1.5636360329510388

size of equipment and in the cost of the house itself.   If you    1.67495327387791

by all means <make provision for its easy adding later>. Manufacturers    1.6065767145351917
have designed equipment for just such circumstances, and your    1.5127085093302464
savings over starting from scratch will be substantial.   If your    1.5636360329510388
house is to have a forced warm air system, cooling can be a part of    1.7269387314284994
it. This costs less than having a completely separate cooling system,    1.6065767145351917

same variety of styles in which you buy a furnace alone- high or    1.67495327387791

Be sure ducts that require insulation get it when they are installed.    1.6432600607208703
They may be inaccessible later. <Be sure your ducts and blower are    1.6432600607208703
big enough to handle cooling>. This is especially important if you    1.6065767145351917

and diffusers that will work as well for cooling as they do for    1.67495327387791

of hot water. Instead of radiators you'll have cooling-heating    1.5127085093302464

more remarkable of the new cooling systems is one that can be switched    1.67495327387791
to heating. As you know, a conditioner makes indoor air cool by pumping    1.67495327387791

simple switching arrangement reverses the cycle so that the machine    1.5636360329510388

at temperatures down to 15 degrees. You can get this added heating    1.6432600607208703

Consider it as a standby setup, at negligible cost, for those    1.6065767145351917

or for cool summer mornings or evenings when you don't want to start    1.67495327387791
up your whole heating plant. _WHAT SIZE CONDITIONER?_ How large    1.5636360329510388
a cooling unit you need, and the method of its installation, depends    1.6432600607208703
on a variety of factors. Among other things, besides the nature of    1.6432600607208703
your house and how much heat finds its way into its various rooms from    1.7026049541338664
the outside, it will depend upon your personal habits and the makeup    1.6432600607208703
of your family. Families with children usually don't want the house    1.6065767145351917
quite so cool. If you are a party thrower, you may need added capacity.    1.7026049541338664
The body is a heat machine, and 20 to 25 guests can easily double    1.7026049541338664
your cooling load.   Cooling requirements are best expressed in    1.5127085093302464
terms of ~BTU's. A ~BTU is a unit of heat, and the ~BTU    1.67495327387791
rating of a conditioner refers to how much heat your machine can    1.6432600607208703
pump <out> of your house in an hour. A very rough rule of thumb is    1.7269387314284994
that, under favorable conditions, you'll need 15 ~BTU's of cooling    1.5636360329510388
for every square foot of your house. This is if outdoor temperatures    1.6432600607208703
have a high average of 95 degrees. You'll need more if the high    1.67495327387791
average is above that, less if it's below.   Coolers are also    1.6065767145351917
rated by tons. A ton of cooling compares to the cooling you get by    1.7026049541338664
melting a ton of ice. By accepted definition, a 1-ton conditioner will    1.6432600607208703
provide 12,000 ~BTU of cooling in one hour.   You may find    1.6065767145351917
a conditioner rated by horsepower. It is generally an inaccurate    1.5636360329510388
method of rating, for the horsepower is that of the compressor motor,    1.6432600607208703
and many other components beside it determine how much cooling you'll    1.6065767145351917
get. A 1-~hp conditioner, for example, may vary in effectiveness    1.5636360329510388
from under 8,000 ~BTU to well over 10,000 ~BTU.   The    1.5636360329510388
safest procedure is to let your builder estimate the size of the unit    1.67495327387791
you need, rather than trying to do this yourself.   Don't urge    1.6065767145351917
your builder to give you a little extra cooling capacity just to be    1.67495327387791
sure you have enough. Better to have your equipment slightly undersized    1.6065767145351917
than too big. Here's why:   Reducing humidity is often    1.5127085093302464
as important as cooling. An oversize unit will cool off your house quickly,    1.67495327387791
then shut down for a long period. Before it cycles on again, humidity    1.67495327387791
can build up and make you uncomfortable even though the temperature    1.6065767145351917
is still low. With a unit of the right size, a compressor will    1.67495327387791
run continuously during hot weather, reducing humidity as evenly as it    1.6065767145351917
does temperature. _MONEY-SAVING TIPS._ Attention to details can    1.4513752902486308
cut in half the size unit you need and pare operating expense proportionately.    1.67495327387791
A well-designed, 1200-square-foot house can be comfortably cooled    1.4513752902486308
and heated for as little as $128 a year, or $11 a month.    1.67495327387791
If you have a house which heat doesn't penetrate easily, your unit    1.6432600607208703
will have less heat to remove. Keep the direct sun from reaching the    1.67495327387791
house and you've won the first battle. In a new house, generous roof    1.67495327387791
overhangs are a logical and effective solution. If the house you plan    1.6432600607208703
to buy or build won't have big overhangs, you can still do a fair    1.7026049541338664
job of keeping the sun off walls and windows with properly designed    1.6432600607208703
trellises, fences and awnings.   Shade trees, too, are a big help,    1.6065767145351917
so keep them if you can. Drawn blinds and draperies do some good,    1.67495327387791
but not nearly as much as shading devices on the outside of the house.   1.7026049541338664
The more directly the sun strikes walls and roof, the greater    1.6065767145351917
its heat impact. The way a house is set on its lot can therefore influence    1.7269387314284994
how much cooling you're going to need. A shift in the walls,    1.6432600607208703
or a change in the roof slope, so the sun hits them more obliquely, can    1.7269387314284994
save you money.   You can use heat-absorbing glass to stop the    1.6065767145351917
sun, double glass and insulated glass to combat condensation. <Restrict    1.5636360329510388
large glass areas to the north and south sides of the house>.    1.6432600607208703
They're easier to shade there. An attic space above insulation makes    1.6065767145351917
a house easier to cool. You'll even gain by putting your water    1.6432600607208703
heater outside the conditioned space, and using an electric range instead    1.6065767145351917
of a gas one. Gas adds to the moisture load.   Insulate, weatherstrip,    1.6432600607208703

Your invitation to write about Serge Prokofieff to honor his    1.5636360329510388
70th Anniversary for the April issue of <Sovietskaya Muzyka> is    1.5636360329510388
accepted with pleasure, because I admire the music of Prokofieff;    1.5636360329510388
and with sober purpose, because the development of Prokofieff personifies,    1.5636360329510388
in many ways, the course of music in the Union of Soviet Socialist    1.67495327387791
Republics.   The Serge Prokofieff whom we knew in the    1.5127085093302464
United States of America was gay, witty, mercurial, full of pranks    1.6065767145351917
and <bonheur>- and very capable as a professional musician. These    1.5636360329510388
qualities endeared him to both the musicians and the social-economic    1.5636360329510388
<haute monde> which supported the concert world of the post-World    1.5636360329510388
War /1, era. Prokofieff's outlook as a composer-pianist-conductor    1.4513752902486308
in America was, indeed, brilliant.   Prokofieff's <Classical>    1.3761581156320553
Symphony was hailed as an ingenious work from a naturally gifted    1.6065767145351917
and well-trained musician still in his twenties. To the Traditionalists,    1.5636360329510388
it was a brilliant satire on modernism; to the Neo-Classicists,    1.5636360329510388
it was a challenge to the pre-war world. What was it to Prokofieff?    1.67495327387791
A tongue-in-cheek stylization of 18th-Century ideas; a trial    1.4513752902486308
balloon to test the aesthetic climate of the times; a brilliant <piece    1.6432600607208703
de resistance?> Certainly its composer was an ascending star    1.5127085093302464
on a new world horizon.   I heard the <Classical> Symphony    1.5636360329510388
for the first time when Koussevitzky conducted it in Paris in 1927.    1.6432600607208703
All musical Paris was there. Some musicians were enthusiastic, some    1.5636360329510388
skeptical. I myself was one of the skeptics (35 years ago). I remember    1.67495327387791
Ernest Bloch in the foyer, shouting in his high-pitched voice:    1.5636360329510388
"**h it may be a <tour de force, mais mon Dieu,> can anyone take    1.7026049541338664
this music seriously"?   The answer is, "Yes"! Certainly,    1.4513752902486308
America took Prokofieff and his <Classical> Symphony seriously,    1.4513752902486308
and with a good deal of pleasure. His life-long friend, Serge    1.6065767145351917
Koussevitzky, gave unreservedly of his praise and brilliant performances    1.5127085093302464

he added broadcastings and recordings for the whole nation. Chicago was    1.6065767145351917

premiere of the <Love for Three Oranges,> and played the first    1.6065767145351917
performance of his Third Piano Concerto. "Uncle Sam" was, indeed,    1.5636360329510388
a rich uncle to Prokofieff, in those opulent, post-war victory    1.5636360329510388
years of peace and prosperity, bold speculations and extravaganzas, enjoyment    1.5636360329510388
and pleasure: "The Golden Twenties". We attended the    1.4513752902486308
premieres of his concertos, symphonies, and suites; we studied, taught,    1.5636360329510388
and performed his piano sonatas, chamber music, gavottes, and marches;    1.5636360329510388
we bought his records and played them in our schools and universities.    1.6432600607208703
We unanimously agreed that Prokofieff had won his rights as    1.5636360329510388
a world citizen to the first ranks of Twentieth-Century Composers.   1.5636360329510388
Nevertheless, Prokofieff was much influenced by Paris during    1.4513752902486308
the Twenties: the Paris which was the artistic center of the Western    1.6432600607208703
World- the social Paris to which Russian aristocracy migrated-    1.5127085093302464
the <chic> Paris which attracted the tourist dollars of rich    1.5636360329510388
America- the <avant-garde> Paris of Diaghileff, Stravinsky, Koussevitzky,    1.4513752902486308
Cocteau, Picasso- the <laissez-faire> Paris of Dadaism    1.3761581156320553

So young Prokofieff was the darling of success: in his motherland;    1.6065767145351917
in the spacious hunting grounds of "Uncle Sam"; in the exciting    1.6065767145351917

of men, minds, and machines, Prokofieff was recalled to his    1.5636360329510388
native land. The world exploded when Fascism challenged all concepts    1.5636360329510388
of peace and liberty, and the outraged, freedom-loving peoples of the    1.6065767145351917
Capitalist and Socialist worlds combined forces to stamp Fascist    1.5127085093302464
tyranny into cringing submission. After this holocaust, a changing world    1.5636360329510388
occupied the minds of men; a world beset with new boundaries, new    1.6432600607208703
treaties and governments, new goals and methods, and the age-old fears    1.6065767145351917
of aggression    1.0
and subjugation- hunger and exposure.   In this    1.3761581156320553
changed world, Prokofieff settled to find himself, and to create    1.5636360329510388
for    1.0
large national purpose. Here, this happy, roving son of good fortune    1.6065767145351917

Here, Prokofieff became a workman in the vineyards of Socialism-    1.5636360329510388

Prokofieff might well emerge as a cultural hero, who, by the force of    1.67495327387791

ROY MASON IS ESSENTIALLY A LANDSCAPE PAINTER whose style and direction    1.6065767145351917
has a kinship with the English watercolorists of the early nineteenth    1.6065767145351917
century, especially the beautifully patterned art of John Sell    1.5127085093302464

distillation of the natural form that inspired them.   As a    1.5636360329510388

he knew best: hunters in the field, fishermen in the stream, ducks    1.6432600607208703
and geese on the wing- almost always against a vast backdrop of    1.6432600607208703
weather landscape. It is this subject matter that has brought Mason    1.6065767145351917
a large and enthusiastic following among sportsmen, but it is his exceptional    1.6432600607208703
performance with this motif that commends him to artists and    1.5636360329510388
discerning collectors.   Mason had to earn the privilege of devoting    1.5636360329510388
himself exclusively to painting. Like many others, he had to work    1.6065767145351917
hard, long hours in a struggling family business which, though it was    1.6432600607208703
allied to art of a kind- the design and production of engraved seals-    1.67495327387791
bore no relation to the painting of pictures. But it did teach    1.6432600607208703
Roy the basic techniques of commercial art, and later, for twelve years,    1.6432600607208703
he and his sister Nina conducted an advertising art studio in Philadelphia.    1.6432600607208703
On the death of their father, they returned to their home    1.6065767145351917
in Batavia, New York. After more years of concentrated effort, Roy    1.6065767145351917
and his brother Max finally established a thriving family business    1.5636360329510388

first only on weekends, and then, as the family business permitted,    1.6065767145351917

except for his continued hunting and fishing expeditions. But even    1.5636360329510388

job is done. Inspiring- yes; instructive- maybe; duplicable-    1.4513752902486308
no!   But for the technical fact, we have the artist's    1.5636360329510388
own testimony:   "Of late years, I find that I like best to    1.6432600607208703
work out-of-doors. First I make preliminary watercolor sketches in    1.5127085093302464
quarter scale (approximately **f inches) in which I pay particular attention    1.6065767145351917
to the design principles of three simple values- the lightest    1.5636360329510388
light, the middle tone, and the darkest dark- by reducing the forms    1.6432600607208703
of my subject to these large patterns. If a human figure or wild life    1.7026049541338664

their surroundings if they are conceived in this early stage, though    1.6065767145351917
I freely admit that I do not hesitate to add or eliminate figures on    1.7026049541338664

convinced that most watercolors suffer because the artist expects    1.5127085093302464
nature will do his composing for him; as a result, such pictures are    1.67495327387791
only a literal translation of what the artist finds in the scene before    1.67495327387791

Out of long experience I have found that incidental figures and other    1.6432600607208703

and crispness, but unless the artist has lots of experience so that    1.6432600607208703

to help each other during their studies, sharing a joint purse,    1.6065767145351917
lodging together in the dormitory and dining together at the home of    1.6432600607208703
their aunt. They supplemented their income by small government assistance,    1.5636360329510388

kingdom of thought and imagination; there is a struggle there, in which,    1.6432600607208703
if he falls, it is easy for him to rise again, there is freedom    1.7026049541338664
of utterance there, which draws after it no irreparable consequences on    1.6065767145351917
society **h. I lived in this onward-driving contest where each day    1.6065767145351917

about science. In this third year at the university, Hans, in 1797,    1.6432600607208703
was awarded the first important token of recognition, a gold medal for    1.6432600607208703
his essay on "Limits of Poetry and Prose". He completed his training    1.6432600607208703
in pharmacy also, taking his degree with high honors in 1797,    1.6065767145351917
and in 1799 was awarded the degree of Doctor of Philosophy along with    1.67495327387791
a prize for an essay in medicine. He proposed a fresh theory of alkalis    1.7026049541338664
which later was accepted in chemical practices.    1.3761581156320553
HAN'S STUDENT DAYS were at a time when Europe    1.5127085093302464
was in a new intellectual ferment following the revolutions in America    1.6065767145351917
and in France, Germany and Italy were rising from divisive nationalisms    1.6065767145351917
and a strong wave of intellectual awareness was sweeping the    1.5636360329510388
Continent.   The new century opened with Oersted beginning    1.4513752902486308
his professional career in charge of an apothecary shop in Copenhagen    1.6065767145351917
and as lecturer at the university. He was stirred by the announcement    1.6432600607208703
of Volta's    1.0
discovery of chemical electricity and he immediately applied    1.4513752902486308
the voltaic pile to experiments with acids and alkalis. The following    1.6065767145351917
year he devoted to the customary "Wanderjahr", traveling in    1.5127085093302464
Germany, France, and the Netherlands, meeting the philosophers Schelling,    1.5127085093302464
Fichte, and Tieck. He also met Count Rumford (born Benjamin    1.5636360329510388
Thompson in Woburn, Mass&) who was then serving the Elector    1.5636360329510388

contacts in science.   From Go^ttingen (1801) where he stayed    1.5127085093302464

about galvanism. As everybody is curious to see the battery of glass    1.6432600607208703
tubes I have invented, I have had quite a small one made here of    1.7026049541338664
four glass    1.0

their correspondence after he left. With Ritter he was exposed    1.5636360329510388

was never awarded to him. In May, 1803, Ritter, in another flight    1.6432600607208703

He related events on earth to periodic celestial phenomena and    1.5636360329510388

into a new epoch in which late in the year 1819 or 1820, you will have    1.748515906000203
to reckon. This we might well witness". Ritter died in 1810 and    1.6432600607208703
Oersted not only lived to see the event occur but was the author of    1.7026049541338664
it.   In 1803 Oersted returned to Copenhagen and applied for    1.5636360329510388

experimenting and lecturing, publishing the results of his experiments    1.5127085093302464
in German and Danish periodicals. In 1806 his ambition was    1.5636360329510388

though not realizing full professorship (ordinarius) until 1817.   1.4513752902486308
During Oersted's attendance at the university, it was poorly    1.5127085093302464
equipped with physical apparatus for experimenting in the sciences.    1.5127085093302464
He was, however, fortunate in his contact with Prof& J& G&    1.6065767145351917
L& Manthey (1769-1842), teacher of chemistry, who, in addition to    1.5636360329510388

nothing has been found comparable with electricity by communication;    1.5127085093302464

depending on electrical distribution that one could not find the slightest    1.6065767145351917
difference **h. The form of galvanic activity is halfway between    1.5636360329510388

than in electricity, and less than in magnetism **h. But in such    1.6432600607208703

THE ASSOCIATION between electric    1.0
(both electrostatic and voltaic) forces and magnetic forces had been    1.5636360329510388
recognized by investigators for many decades. Electrical literature    1.4513752902486308
contained numerous references to lightning that had magnetized iron and    1.5636360329510388
had altered the polarity of compass needles. In the late 1700's    1.6065767145351917
Beccaria and van Marum, among others, had magnetized iron by sending    1.6065767145351917
an electrostatic charge through it. Beccaria had almost stumbled on    1.5636360329510388
a lead to the relationship between electricity and magnetism when a discharge    1.6432600607208703
from a Leyden jar was sent <transversally> through a piece    1.5636360329510388
of watch-spring steel making its ends magnetic. The resulting magnetic    1.5636360329510388
effect proved stronger than when the discharge was made lengthwise.    1.5636360329510388
The experiments of Romagnosi and others have already been noted but    1.6065767145351917
no one had determined the cause-and-effect relationship between these    1.5127085093302464
two primary forces. Oersted's own earlier experiments were unimpressive,    1.5127085093302464
possibly because he had, like other experimenters, laid the conducting    1.5636360329510388
wire across the compass needle instead of parallel with it.   1.5636360329510388
The sequence of events leading to his important discovery still remains    1.6065767145351917
ambiguous but it seems that one of the advanced students at the    1.6432600607208703
university related that the first direct event that led to the publication    1.6432600607208703
of Oersted's discovery occurred during a private lecture made    1.5127085093302464
before a group of other advanced students in the spring of 1820. At    1.67495327387791
this lecture Oersted happened to place the conducting wire over and parallel    1.6432600607208703
to a magnetic needle.    1.0

There are three principal feed bunk types for dairy and beef cattle:    1.6432600607208703
(1) Fence-line bunks- cattle eat from one side while feed    1.5636360329510388
is put in from the opposite side of the fence by self-unloading wagons;    1.67495327387791
(2) Mechanized bunks- they sit within the feed lot, are filled    1.6065767145351917
by a mechanical conveyor above feeding surface; (3) Special bunks-    1.5636360329510388
as discussed here, they permit cattle to eat from all sides. Feed is    1.67495327387791
put in with an elevator.   Several materials or combinations of    1.5636360329510388
materials can be used to construct a satisfactory feed bunk. The selection    1.6432600607208703
of materials depends on skills of available labor for installation,    1.5636360329510388
cost of materials available locally, and your own preference. No    1.5636360329510388
one material is best for all situations. Selecting bunks by economic    1.6065767145351917
comparison is usually an individual problem.    1.2818970554302986
Animals eat only from one side, so the fence-line bunk must be twice    1.67495327387791
as long as the mechanical bunk. These bunks also serve as a fence,    1.67495327387791
so part of the additional cost must be attributed to the fence. Because    1.67495327387791
of their location, on the edge of the feed lot, fence-line bunks are    1.67495327387791
not in the way of mechanical manure removal. Filling these bunks by    1.6432600607208703
the same self-unloading wagons used to fill silos spreads cost of the    1.6432600607208703
wagons over more time and operations.   All-weather roads must    1.5127085093302464
be provided next to the feeding floor so access will be possible all    1.67495327387791
year. This will be a problem in areas of heavy snowfall.    1.6065767145351917

their sales manpower and tested new selling, distribution, and promotion    1.5636360329510388
techniques to gain a bigger competitive edge.   Given this    1.5127085093302464
kind of business climate, what competitive marketing problems will your    1.5636360329510388
company face in the next 10 yr&? Based on our experience with    1.6432600607208703

There has been an intensification of price-consciousness in recent    1.5127085093302464

The controversy of the last few years over whether architects or interior    1.6432600607208703
designers should plan the interiors of modern buildings has brought    1.5636360329510388
clearly into focus one important difference of opinion. The architects    1.5636360329510388
do not believe that the education of the interior designer is sufficiently    1.6432600607208703
good or sufficiently extended to compare with that of the architect    1.6065767145351917
and that, therefore, the interior designer is incapable of understanding    1.5636360329510388
the architectural principles involved in planning the interior    1.4513752902486308
of a building.   Ordinary politeness may have militated against    1.5127085093302464
this opinion being stated so badly but anyone with a wide acquaintance    1.6432600607208703
in both groups and who has sat through the many round tables, workshops    1.67495327387791
or panel discussions- whatever they are called- on this subject    1.5636360329510388
will recognize that the final, boiled down crux of the matter is    1.6432600607208703
education.   It is true that most architectural schools have five    1.5636360329510388
year courses, some even have six or more. The element of public danger    1.67495327387791
which enters so largely into architectural certification, however,    1.4513752902486308
would demand a prolonged study of structure. This would, naturally,    1.5636360329510388
lengthen their courses far beyond the largely esthetic demands of interior    1.6065767145351917
designer's training.   We may then dismiss the time difference    1.5127085093302464
between these courses and the usual four year course of the interior    1.6432600607208703
design student as not having serious bearing on the subject. The    1.6065767145351917
real question that follows is- how are those four years used and what    1.67495327387791
is their value as training?   The American Institute of Interior    1.5636360329510388
Designers has published a recommended course for designers and    1.5127085093302464
a percentage layout of such a course. An examination of some forty    1.6432600607208703
catalogs of schools offering courses in interior design, for the most    1.6065767145351917
part schools accredited by membership in the National Association of    1.5636360329510388
Schools of Art, and a further "on the spot" inspection of a number    1.67495327387791
of schools, show their courses adhere pretty closely to the recommendations.    1.6065767145351917
One or two of the schools have a five year curriculum, but    1.6432600607208703
the usual pattern of American education has limited most of them to    1.6432600607208703
the four-year plan which seems to be the minimum in acceptable institutions.   1.6432600607208703
The suggested course of the A&I&D& was based    1.4513752902486308

Without comparing the relative merits of the two courses- architecture    1.5636360329510388

plans and furnishes interiors of houses, commercial and institutional    1.5127085093302464
structures, hotels, clubs, ships, theaters, as well as set    1.5127085093302464
decorations for motion picture arts and television. Makes drawings and    1.5636360329510388
plans of rooms showing placement of furniture, floor coverings, wall    1.5636360329510388
decorations, and determines color schemes.   Furnishes complete    1.3761581156320553
cost estimates for clients approval. Makes necessary purchases, places    1.5127085093302464
contracts, supervises construction, installation, finishing and placement    1.3761581156320553

He must be capable of designing for and supervising the manufacture    1.6065767145351917

WE WERE CAMPING a few weeks ago on Cape Hatteras Campground in    1.6432600607208703
that land of pirates, seagulls and bluefish on North Carolina's    1.5636360329510388
famed Outer Banks. This beach campground with no trees or hills presents    1.6432600607208703
a constant camping show with all manner of equipment in actual    1.6065767145351917
use.   With the whole camp exposed to view we could see the variety    1.67495327387791
of canvas shelters in which Americans are camping now. There were    1.6065767145351917
umbrella tents, wall tents, cottage tents, station wagon tents, pup    1.5636360329510388
tents, Pop tents, Baker tents, tents with exterior frames, camper trailers,    1.6065767145351917
travel trailers, and even a few surplus parachutes serving as    1.5636360329510388
sunshades over entire family camps.   Moving around camp we saw    1.5636360329510388
all kinds of camp stoves, lanterns, coolers, bedding, games, fishing tackle,    1.6065767145351917
windbreaks and sunshades. We saw similar displays in the other    1.5636360329510388
three campgrounds in this 70 mile-long National Seashore Recreation    1.5127085093302464
Area. Dealers would do well to visit such a campground often, look    1.6432600607208703
at the equipment and talk with the campers. Here you begin to appreciate    1.67495327387791
the scope of the challenges and possibilities facing the industry.   1.5636360329510388
Camping is big and getting bigger. No one knows where it will    1.6432600607208703
stop. Almost every official who reflects on it thinks this movement    1.6065767145351917
of Americans to canvas dwellings opens one of the most promising of    1.6432600607208703
all outdoor markets. You read various guesses on how many Americans    1.6065767145351917
are camping. The number depends on who is talking at the moment. The    1.67495327387791
figures range as high as 15 million families. I've heard 10 million    1.6432600607208703
mentioned often, but I'm more inclined to think there may be a    1.6432600607208703
total of some five to seven million families camping. Seven million families    1.6432600607208703
would total 30 million Americans or more. Consider the equipment    1.5636360329510388
needed to protect this many from the weather, to make their cooking    1.6432600607208703
easy and their sleeping comfortable.    1.1606783668269585
Harassed state park officials often have more campers than they    1.5636360329510388
know what to do with. They are struggling to meet the demand for camping    1.7026049541338664
space, but families are being turned away, especially on holiday    1.5636360329510388
weekends. The National Parks, always popular camping places, are facing    1.5636360329510388
the same pressure. The National Park Service hopes by 1966 to    1.6065767145351917
have 30,000 campsites available for 100,000 campers a day- almost    1.5636360329510388
twice what there are at present. The U& S& Forest Service cares    1.6432600607208703
for hundreds of thousands of campers in its 149 National Forests    1.6065767145351917
and is increasing its facilities steadily.   But the campers still    1.5636360329510388
come. They bring their families and tents and camp kitchens and bedding.    1.6432600607208703
They bring their fishing rods and binoculars and bathing suits.    1.5636360329510388
They come prepared for family fun because Americans in ever-growing    1.5636360329510388
numbers are learning that here is the way to a fine economical vacation    1.67495327387791
that becomes a family experience of lasting importance.    1.4513752902486308
There are a half dozen reasons helping to account for    1.5636360329510388
the migration to the campgrounds. Among them, according to the U&    1.6065767145351917
S& Department of Commerce, are: (1) shorter work weeks, (2)    1.5636360329510388
higher pay, (3) longer paid vacations, (4) better transportation, (5)    1.5636360329510388
earlier retirement, and (6) more education. The more people learn about    1.6065767145351917
their country, the more they want to learn. Camping is family fun,    1.6432600607208703
and it is helping more Americans see more of the country than they ever    1.7026049541338664
saw before.   But make no mistake about it, the first reason    1.6065767145351917
people turn to camping is one of economy. Here is the promise of a vacation    1.7269387314284994
trip they can afford.   The American Automobile Association,    1.4513752902486308
computing the cost for two people to vacation by automobile, comes    1.6065767145351917
up with an average daily expenditure figure of $29. The ~AAA    1.6065767145351917
then splits it down this way: $10.50 for meals, $9.50 for lodging,    1.6432600607208703
$7 for gas and oil, and $2 for tips and miscellaneous.   What does    1.67495327387791
the camping couple do to this set of figures? The $9.50 for lodging    1.67495327387791
they save. Because they prepare their own meals they also keep in    1.6432600607208703
their pockets a good portion of that $10.50 food bill along with most    1.67495327387791
of the tip money. The automobile expenses are about the only vacationing    1.6432600607208703
cost they can't either eliminate or pare down drastically by camping    1.6065767145351917
along the way.   Where Americans used to think of a single    1.6065767145351917
vacation each summer, they now think about how many vacations they    1.6065767145351917
can have. Long weekends enable many to get away from home for three or    1.7026049541338664
four days several times a year. And even if they stay in resorts part    1.7026049541338664
of the time, they might, if the right salesman gets them in tow, develop    1.7026049541338664
a yearning to spice the usual vacation fare with a camping trip    1.6432600607208703
into the wide open spaces.   It would be a mistake to sell those    1.67495327387791
thousands of beginning campers on the idea they're buying the comforts    1.6065767145351917
of home. They're not. Home is the place to find the comforts of    1.67495327387791
home. They're buying fun and adventure and family experiences. But    1.5636360329510388
it would also be a mistake for them not to realize how comfortable    1.67495327387791
camping has become. This is no longer a way of life for the bearded    1.7026049541338664
logger and the wandering cowboy. Today's campers want comforts, and    1.5636360329510388
they have them. And this helps explain why so many people are now going    1.7026049541338664
camping. It's fun, and it's easy- so easy that there is time    1.6432600607208703
left after cooking, and tent keeping, for the women to get out and    1.67495327387791
enjoy outdoor fun with their families.   Camp meals are no great    1.6065767145351917
problem. Neither are beds, thanks to air mattresses and sleeping bags.    1.6065767145351917
Neither are shelters, because there is one to meet the needs of every    1.67495327387791
camper or prospective camper.   But there is still the sometimes    1.5636360329510388
complex problem of helping campers choose the best equipment for    1.5636360329510388

SIXTY MILES NORTH of New York City where the wooded hills    1.6065767145351917
of Dutchess County meet the broad sweep of the Hudson River there    1.6432600607208703

**h its oil for heating is metered monthly to each home from a line    1.7026049541338664

sponsored by a new entity chartered in Delaware as the Tri-State    1.6065767145351917

Its president is Otis M& Waters, partner in the law firm of Timen    1.67495327387791
+ Waters, 5404 Chrysler Bldg&, New York City. Vice-president    1.4513752902486308
is Louis Berkman and the secretary-treasurer is Mark Ritter.    1.5127085093302464
Ritter is the builder of Oakwood Heights and president of Kahler-Craft    1.6065767145351917
Distributors, Inc&, Newburgh, N&Y&.   The idea    1.2818970554302986
of a central tank with lines to each house is not in itself a novelty.    1.7269387314284994

knew of one example to point to, a public housing development of 278    1.67495327387791

EVERY YEAR about this time National Gargle Your Cooling    1.5127085093302464
System week rolls around. It pays in the long (hot) run to take good    1.7026049541338664
care of the water works. Do it this way for the summer gargle:   1.67495327387791
@ First, drain that old coolant down the storm sewer. Don't    1.5636360329510388
save the anti-freeze, even if it the expensive "permanent" type.    1.5636360329510388
The word means it won't boil away easily, nothing else. The rust    1.6432600607208703
inhibitors in the fluid are used up after one year, and you don't want    1.7026049541338664
to risk the rust that two years' use could mean. Pitch it out.   1.67495327387791
@ If a lot of rust shows in the drain, use a good flushing cleaner.   1.7026049541338664
@ Then fill the system and add a rust inhibitor. Of    1.5636360329510388
course, you'll want to use the softest water you can in your radiators.   1.67495327387791
@ Now, check for leaks in your hoses and hose connections,    1.5636360329510388
around the freeze-out plugs, gaskets, water pump seals and heater    1.5636360329510388
fittings.   @ Next, run the engine and let it heat up so the thermostat    1.67495327387791
opens, and then look for leaks again. Be sure the bugs and    1.6432600607208703
dirt are blown out of the radiator fins. Use the air hose for this job.    1.7269387314284994
Check the temperature gage and be sure it is working.   If you    1.6432600607208703
use one of the new year-round cooling system fluids such as "Dowguard"    1.6432600607208703
be sure to check it. Dow says that the fluid can be used now    1.7026049541338664
for two years. Check its inhibitor effectiveness before leaving it in    1.6065767145351917
during the summer.   Take precautions now, to be sure you avoid    1.6065767145351917
those unpleasant and costly heat breakdowns when the temperature zooms    1.5636360329510388
this summer.   {Don't let your mechanics} pull the thermostats    1.5127085093302464
out of those fueloil delivery trucks or installation rigs of yours.    1.6065767145351917
Spring and summer may be here officially, but those thermos stay    1.6065767145351917
in.   The fact is that removing and leaving out a thermostat from    1.6432600607208703
any water cooled vehicle, will greatly increase the fuel consumption,    1.5636360329510388
reduce power and contribute to spark plug fouling due to an accumulation    1.6432600607208703
of excessive carbon deposits on the insulators.   If you    1.5127085093302464
run into excess plug fouling on one truck, check to be sure that the rig    1.7269387314284994
has a thermostat. The thermostat is important to get your engine up    1.6432600607208703
to operating temperature quickly, and to keep it running at its most    1.6432600607208703
efficient temperature through the proper circulation of the coolant.   1.5127085093302464
{Are you paying too much} for your truck insurance? There's    1.5636360329510388
a good chance you are doubling on some coverage, not taking discounts    1.6432600607208703
coming to you and not cutting some corners that can be cut.   1.6432600607208703
Have a talk with your insurance agent. Be careful that you keep    1.6432600607208703
adequate coverage, but look for places to save money. First go over the    1.67495327387791
type of coverage you now have. Look for these features which may mean    1.67495327387791
you can save:   @ Duplicate coverage. Avoid doubling up    1.4513752902486308
on the same item. For example, don't pay in a truck policy for medical    1.7026049541338664
coverage that you may be paying for in a health and accident policy.   1.67495327387791
@ Does your policy have a lay-up clause? This means that    1.5636360329510388
if your insured vehicle is laid up for more than 30 days, insurance    1.67495327387791
can be suspended and a proportionate return of your premium made to    1.6432600607208703
you. This applies to repair work or winter storage.   The figure    1.6065767145351917
five is important in insurance. With many company policies you get    1.6065767145351917
a fleet discount if you insure five or more rigs. This means either cars    1.7026049541338664
or trucks. Discounts run up to 2% of cost.   Usually premium    1.6065767145351917
reductions can be obtained by applying deductibles to your liability    1.5636360329510388
plan. For example: If your bodily injury claims start payment after    1.6065767145351917
the first $250, a 25% premium saving is often made.    1.5636360329510388

FROM    1.0
Don't insert your components into fixed openings,    1.3761581156320553
they may or may not fit; position your components before you close    1.6432600607208703
them in. For example:   Don't wall in your kitchen before    1.5636360329510388
you hang the wall cabinets and set the appliances. It's a lot quicker    1.67495327387791
and easier to dimension the kitchen to fit the cabinets and erect    1.6432600607208703
the end wall after they are all in place.   Set your bathtub before    1.67495327387791
you close in the end of the bathroom. Don't try to wrestle a    1.67495327387791
400-~lb tub **f through a narrow doorway.   Finish your plumbing    1.5636360329510388
before you frame it in (most economical framing is a thin non-bearing    1.6432600607208703
partition on either side of the pipes).   Finish installing and    1.5636360329510388
connecting up your furnace and your water heater before you wall them    1.6432600607208703
in. There is no better way to waste time than trying to install a    1.7026049541338664
furnace in a finished **f closet.   Don't position your studs    1.5636360329510388
before you insert your windows in conventional construction; that way    1.5636360329510388
you may pay more to shim the window into place than you paid for the    1.7269387314284994
window. You can save all that shimming time if you set your windows    1.67495327387791
in one, two, three order- first the stud on one side, then the window,    1.7026049541338664
then the stud on the other side.   Install your disappearing    1.5636360329510388
stair (or stairs) to the attic and finish your overhead ducts before    1.6432600607208703
you drywall the ceiling.   Don't close in your house until everything    1.6065767145351917
has been carried in. Last wall Bob Schmitt erects is the wall    1.6432600607208703
between the house and garage. That way he can truck his parts right    1.67495327387791
indoors and unload them under the roof.   No auto maker would    1.6065767145351917

in the block. And trailer makers, those most industrialized and therefore    1.6065767145351917

by always building from the inside out.    1.3761581156320553

_@_ Farming is confining. The farmer's life must be arranged    1.5127085093302464

during the growing season.   The worker who lives on a farm    1.6065767145351917
cannot change jobs readily. He cannot leave the farm to take work    1.6432600607208703
in another locality on short notice; such a move may mean a loss of    1.7026049541338664
capital. _@_ Hard physical labor and undesirable hours are a part    1.5636360329510388
of farm life. The farmer must get up early, and, at times, work late    1.7026049541338664
at night. Frequently he must work long hours in the hot sun or cold    1.7026049541338664
rain. No matter how well work is planned, bad weather or unexpected    1.6432600607208703
setbacks can cause extra work that must be caught up.   It may    1.6432600607208703
